hom.sense: The third letter of the alphabet: called taMCN and taA [respecting which latter see the letter b]: the pl. [of the former is taMCaAtN; and of the latter,] OatowaMCu. (TA in bAb AlAlf Allyin-p.) It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice], and of those termed niTaEiy-ap [and niToEiy-ap and naTaEiy-ap and naToEiy-ap pronounced by pressing the tip of the tongue against the upper gums and suddenly withdrawing it with an emission of the breath]: these latter are T and d and t, three letters that are among those which are changed into other letters. (TA at the commencement of bAb AltMC.)

It is one of the augmentative letters: (Ṣ:) and is movent when added at the beginning of a noun, and at the end of a noun, [and at the beginning of a verb,] and at the end of a verb, and is also quiescent at the end of a verb. (Mughnee, Ḳ.)

Added at the beginning of a noun, it is a preposition, or particle governing the gen. case, significant of swearing, (Ṣ,* Mughnee, Ḳ,) and denoting wonder; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and [accord. to general usage] it is peculiarly prefixed to the name Qll-eh; (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) as in taQll-ehi laqado kaAna kacaA [By God, verily it was thus, or verily such a thing was]; (Ṣ;) and taQll-ehi laOafoEalan-a kacaA [By God, I will assuredly do such a thing]: (TA:) but sometimes they said, tarab-iI [By my Lord], and tarab-i AlkaEobapi [By the Lord of the Kaabeh], and taQlr-aHomaAni [By the Compassionate], (Mughnee, Ḳ,) as is related on the authority of Akh; deviating from common usage. (TA.) Thus used, it is a substitute for w, (Ṣ, Mughnee,) as it is also in tatoraI and turaAvN and tujaAha and tuxamapN [&c.]; (Ṣ;) and the w is a substitute for b; (Ṣ, Mughnee;) but the t has the additional meaning of denoting wonder: so says Z. (Mughnee.)

Added at the end of a noun, it is a particle of allocution: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) it is thus added in Oanota [Thou], (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) addressed to a male, (TA,) and Oanoti [Thou], (Mughnee, Ḳ,) addressed to a female; (TA;) uniting with the noun, as though the two became one; not being an affixed noun governed in the gen. case. (Ṣ. [See Oano.])

It is added in [the beginning of] the second person of the future, (Ṣ,) [i. e.,] in the beginning of the aor., (TA,) [as a particle of allocution,] as in Oanota tafoEalu [Thou dost, or wilt do]. (Ṣ, TA.)
It is also added, as a sign of the fem. gender, in the beginning of the future, [or aor.,] as in hiIa tafoEalu [She does, or will do]. (Ṣ, TA.)
It is also added in the beginning of the third person [fem.] of the [aor. used as an] imperative, [as a sign of the fem. gender,] as in litaqumo hinodu [Let Hind stand]. (TA.)

And sometimes it is added in the beginning of the second person of the [aor. used as an] imperative, [as a particle of allocution,] as in the phrase in the Ḳur [x. 59, accord. to one reading], fabicelika falotaforaHuwA [Therefore therein rejoice ye]: and in the saying of the rájiz,
qulotu libaw-aAbK ladayohi daAruhaA
tiYocano faUin-iI HamoWuhaA wajaAruhaA
[explained in art.Acn]: and [thus] it is added in the beginning of [the second person of] the [aor. used as an] imperative of a verb of which the agent is not named, as in lituzoha yaA rajulu [Be thou proud, vain, boastful, or self-conceited, O man], from zuhiIa: but Akh says that the adding of the l in the beginning of the second person of the [aor. used as an] imperative [except in the case of a pass. verb or a verb of which the agent is not named] is a bad idiom, because the l is not needed. (Ṣ, TA.)

The movent t added at the end of a verb is a pronoun, as in qumotu [I stood], (Mughnee, Ḳ,) and qumota [Thou stoodest, addressed to a male], and qumoti [Thou stoodest, addressed to a female]: (Mughnee:) thus added in the first and second persons of the pret., it is a pronoun denoting the agent. (Ṣ.)

The quiescent t added at the end of a verb is a sign of the fem. gender, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) i. e., a particle applied to denote the fem. gender, (Mughnee,) as in qaAmato [She stood]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) J says [in the Ṣ] that, when thus added at the end of the pret., it is a pronoun: but IB says [correctly] that it is a particle. (TA.)
It is also, sometimes, affixed to vum-a and rub-a; and in these cases it is most commonly movent with fet-ḥ, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) so that one says vum-ata and rub-ata. (TA.) [See arts. vm and rb.]
ti is an imperative of OataI. (M in art. AtI.)
[As a numeral, t denotes Four hundred.]

taA fem. of caA; (M;) i. q. ciho [This and that]; (T;) a noun of indication, denoting that which is female or feminine; like caA (Ṣ, Ḳ) applied to that which is male or masculine; (Ṣ;) and you say also tiho, like ciho: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the dual is taAni: and the pl., OuwlaMCi. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee] says, (T, Ṣ,) excusing himself to En-Noamán [Aboo-Káboos], whom he had satirized, (TA,)
haA Uin-a taA EicorapN Uino lamo takuno nafaEato
faUin-a SaAHibahaA qado taAha fiI Albaladi
[Now verily this is an excuse: if it profit not, then verily its author has lost his way in the desert, or in the waterless desert]: (T, Ṣ: but in the latter, lA is put in the place of lm:) tA here points to the qaSiydap [or ode]; and Ecrp is a subst from AiEoticaArN; and tAh means taHay-ara; and Albld means AlmafaAzap. (TA.) The dim. of taA is tay-aA, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is anomalous, like cay-aA the dim. of caA, &c. (I’Aḳ p. 343.) [Much has been written respecting the formation of this dim. to reduce it to something like rule, but I pass it over as, in my opinion, unprofitable and unsatisfactory; and only refer to what is said respecting the duals Oulay-aA and Oulay-aMCi in art. AlI. See an ex. voce mir-apN.]

haA is prefixed to it (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) [as an inceptive particle] to give notice of what is about to be said, (Ṣ,) so that one says haAtaA [meaning This], (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) as in haAtaA fulaAnapu [This is such a woman]; (T;) and [in the dual] haAtaAni; and [in the pl.] heWulaMCi: and the dim. is haAtay-aA. (Ṣ.)

When you use it in addressing another person, you add to it k [as a particle of allocution], and say taAka (Ṣ, Ḳ) and tiyka and tiloka (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and taloka, which is a bad dial. var., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and taAlika, (T, Ṣ,) which is the worst of these: (T:) [all meaning That:] the dual is taAnika and taAn-ika, the latter with teshdeed, (Ṣ, Ḳ, [but in some copies of the Ṣ, only the latter is mentioned,]) and taAlika [which, like taAn-ika, is dual of tiloka or taloka, which are contractions of taAlika; these two duals being for taAnilika, the original, but unused, form]: (Ḳ:) the pl. is OuwleYika [or OuwlaMYika] and OuwlaAka and OuwlaAlika [respecting all of which see OulaI, in art. AlI]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the dim. is tay-aAka and tay-aAlika: (Ḳ: [in the TA, the latter is erroneously written tay-Anika:]) the k relates to the person or persons whom you address, masc. and fem. and dual and pl.: [but in addressing a female, you may say taAki, &c.; in addressing two persons, taAkumaA, &c.; in addressing more than two males, taAkumo, &c.; and in addressing more than two females, taAkun-a, &c.:] what precedes the k relates to the person [or thing] indicated, masc. and fem. and dual and pl. (Ṣ.)

haA is also prefixed to tiyka and taAka, so that one says, haAtiyka hinodu and haAtaAka hinodu [This, or that, is Hind]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) Abu-n-Nejm says,
jiYonaA nuHay-iyka wanasotajodiykaA
faQfoEalo binaA haAtaAka Oawo haAtiykaA
meaning [We have come saluting thee and seeking of thee a gift: then do thou to us] this or that: [give us] a salutation or a gift. (Ṣ.) The haA that is used to give notice of what is about to be said is not prefixed to tlk because the l is made a substitute for that hA: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as IB says, they do not prefix that hA to celika and tiloka because the l denotes the remoteness of that which is indicated and the hA denotes its nearness, so that the two are incompatible. (TA.)
taA and tMCN Names of the letter t: see that letter, and see arts. twO and tI.
taA and taOaA or taM for taXaMC: see (near its end) art. A.

entry.sense: R. Q. 1. taOotaOa, inf. n. tOotaOapN, He reiterated the letter t in speaking. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
taOotaOa biAlt-ayosi, (T, M,) inf. n. as above (T, M, Ḳ) and tiYotaMCN, (M,) or taOotaMCN, (Ḳ,) He called the he-goat to copulate, (T, M, Ḳ,) or to approach, (M,) saying taOo taOo↓. (M.)
taOo taOo: see what next precedes.
taOotaOapN An onomatopœia [imitative of the sound made in reiterating the letter t in speaking: or, in calling a he-goat to copulate, or to approach: see the verb, above]. (T, Ḳ.)
taOotaMCN A man who reiterates the letter t in speaking. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

4. OatoOarotu Uilayohi Aln-aZara I continued to look at him time after time (taArapF baEoda taArapK): (T, TA:) or I looked at him sharply, or intently. (Fr, T, M, Ḳ.) And OatoOarotuhu baSariI, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and OatoOarotu Uilayohi AlbaSara, (Ḳ,) I followed him with my eye; made my eye to follow him. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) [See also art. twr.]

taArapN, without C on account of frequent usage, (IAạr, T, Mṣb in art. twr, and Ḳ,) A time; one time; [in the sense of the French fois;] syn. mar-apN: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a time, whether long or short; syn. HiynN: (IAạr:) sometimes, however, it is pronounced taOorapN: (Mṣb:) pl. tiYarN (T, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tiYaArN: (Mṣb:) these are pls. of taOorapN; but the pl. of taArapN without C is taAraAtN (Mṣb) and tiyarN (Ṣ in art. tyr, and Ḳ and Ḳ in art. twr,) and tiyaArN. (Ṣ in art. tyr.) [See also art. twr.]

mutaArN in the saying
faSirotu kaOan-aniI faraON mutaAru
is [said by ISd to be] for mutoOarN [pass. part. n. of OatoOara; so that the meaning is, And I became as though I were a wild ass looked at sharply or intently, or followed by the eye, in order to be captured or shot]. (M, TA. [But see art. twr.])
3. taMCama OaxaAhu, (Ḳ, TA, [in the TT, as from the M, written taOama, and so by Golius,]) inf. n. mutaMCamapN, (TA,) He was twinborn with his brother. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

tMCm, (Ṣ,) or tMCm vawobFA, (M, Ḳ, TA, [in the TT, again, written taOama,]) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, TA,) † He wove a piece of cloth of threads two and two together (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) in its warp and its woof. (Ḳ.) [See mitoMmN, and see also niyrN.]
tMCm Alfarasu, (Ḳ, [written by Golius taOama,]) inf. n. as above, (TA,) † The horse fetched run after run. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. OatoOamato She (a mother, Ḳ, or a woman, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, and any pregnant animal, M) twinned, or brought forth two at one birth. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
OatoOamahaA i. q. OafoDaAhaA [like MtamahaA, q. v. in art. Atm]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Golius and Freytag have rendered it as though it meant OafoDaI UilayohaA.]

entry.sense: tiYomN, whence huwa tiYomuhu: see tawoCamN.
taYiymN, whence huwa taYiymuhu: see tawoCamN.

tuWaAmiy-apN A pearl; (M, Ḳ;) so called in relation to tuWaAmN, (TA,) which is a town twenty leagues from the metropolis of 'Omán, (Ḳ, TA,) in the tract next the sea, (TA,) a city of 'Omán whence pearls are purchased, (M,) erroneously called by J tawoCamN, [but in one copy of the Ṣ I find it written tuwAm,] and said by him to be the metropolis of 'Omán; (Ḳ;) as also tawoCamiy-apN↓, (TA, [and thus it is written in copies of the Ṣ, but in one copy I find it written tuwAmiy-ap,]) thought by En-Nejeeremee to be thus called in relation to the oyster-shell, because this is always what is termed tawoCamN, q. v. (TA.)

tawoCamN A twin; one of two young, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of more, (M, Ḳ,) brought forth at one birth, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of any animals; whether a male or a female, or a male [brought forth] with a female; (M, Ḳ;) and tawoCamapN is [also] applied to a female: (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it occurs in poetry contracted into tawamN: (M:) the pl. is tawaAYimu and tuWaAmN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter of which is of a rare form, not without parallels, (M,) said by some to be a quasi-pl. n., and by some to be originally [tiYaAmN,] with kesr, but the assertion of these last is condemned by AḤei; (MF;) and tawoCamuwna is allowable as applied to human beings: (Ṣ, TA:) you say, huwa tawoCamuhu [in the TA, erroneously, tuWomuhu, with damm,] and tiYomuhu↓ and taYiymuhu↓ [in the CK tayoYmuhu] (AZ, M, Ḳ) [meaning He is his twin-brother]: and humaA tawoCamaAni (Ṣ,* M, Mgh, Mṣb * Ḳ) and tawoCamN (M, Ḳ) [They two are twin-brothers]: or tawoCamN applies only to one of the two; (Mṣb;) it is a mistake to say humaA tawoCamN and humaA zawojN: (Mgh:) [but see zawojN:] Lth says that tawoCamN applies to two sons, or young ones, [born] together; and that one should not say humaA tawoCamaAni, but humaA tawoCamN: this, however, is a mistake: correctly, as ISk and Fr say, tawoCamN applies to one, and tawoCamaAni to two. (T, TA.) It is of the measure fawoEalN, (Kh, Ṣ, IB, Mṣb,) in the opinion of some, (IB,) and originally wawoCamN, (Kh, T, Ṣ, IB,) like as tawolajN is originally wawolajN; (Kh, T, Ṣ;) from AlwiYaAmu, (T, IB,) “the being mutually near,” (T,) “mutually agreeing,” (T, IB,) “being mutually conformable;” (IB;) so that it means one that agrees with, or matches, another, (IB.)

It is metaphorically used in relation to all things resembling one another [so that it means ‡ One of a pair]. (M.) A poet says,
qaAlato lanaA wadamoEuhaA tuWaAmu
kaQld-ur-i Uico Oasolamahu Qln-iZaAmu
EalaI Ql-aciyna QrotaHaluwA Qls-alaAmu
† [She said to us, while her tears fell in pairs, or in close succession, like large pearls when the string lets them drop off, Upon those who have departed be peace]. (Ṣ.) [This citation, and what immediately follows it in the Ṣ, mentioning the pl. tawoCamuwna, not tuWaAmuwna, have been misunderstood by Golius; and Freytag has followed him in this case.]

Alt-awoCamu is also [a name of] † A certain Mansion [of the Moon; namely, the Sixth; more commonly called AlhanoEapu;] pertaining to AljawozaMC [here meaning Gemini]; (M, Ḳ;) one of two [asterisms] called tawoCamaAni: (M:) Alt-awoCamaAni is † The Sign of Gemini. (Ḳzw.)
[The pl.] tawaAYimu also signifies † Clusters, or what are clustered together, (maA taXaAbaka,) of stars, and of pearls. (M, Ḳ.)
And tawoCamaAni, † A pair of pearls, or large pearls, for the ear: each of them is termed a tawoCamap to the other. (TA.)

Alt-awoCamaAni, [in the CK Alt-awoCamAnu,] † A certain small herb, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,) having a fruit like cumin-seed, (AḤn, M, and Ḳ in art. wOm,) and many leaves, growing in the plains, spreading long and wide, and having a yellow flower. (AḤn, TA.)

Alt-awoCamu also signifies † The arrow of the kind used in the game called Almayosir: (M:) or a certain arrow of those used in that game: (Ḳ:) or the second of those arrows; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) said by Lḥ to have two notches, and to entitle to two portions [of the slaughtered camel] if successful, and to subject to the payment for two portions if unsuccessful. (M.)

And tawoCamaAtN, † A kind of women's vehicles [borne by camels], (T, Ḳ,) like the maXaAjir, (T, TA,) erroneously said in the copies of the Ḳ to be like the maXaAjib, (TA,) having no coverings, or canopies: the sing. is tawoCamapN. (T, Ḳ.)
tawoCamiy-apN: see tuWaAmiy-apN.
mutoYimN Twinning, or bringing forth two at one birth; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a mother, (Ḳ,) or a woman, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and to any pregnant animal; (M;) without p. (Mṣb.)
mitoMmN Accustomed to twin, or bring forth two at one birth; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) applied to a mother, (Ḳ,) or a woman, (Ṣ, M,) and to any pregnant animal: (M:) pl. mataAYiymu. (Ḥar p. 613.)
Hence, (Ḥar ubi suprà,) vawobN mitoMmN, (Ṣ, Ḥar,) or mutaMCamN↓, (TA, PṢ,) [both app. correct,] † A piece of cloth woven of threads two and two together in its warp and its woof. (Ṣ, Ḥar, TA.)
Hence, also, OaboyaAtN mataAYiymu ‡ Verses consisting of words in pairs whereof each member resembles the other in writing. (Ḥar ubi suprà.) [See also mutawoCamN.]
mutaMCamN: see mitoMmN.
farasN mutaAYimN † A horse fetching, or that fetches, run after run. (Ṣ, M.)

hom.sense: 1. [tab-a, aor. _i {yatobibu}, inf. n. tab-N, and perhaps tababN↓ and tabaAbN↓ and tabiybN↓, He, or it, suffered loss, or diminution; or became lost: and perished, or died: as also tb-b↓, inf. n. tatobiybN: and app. tub-a also.] tab-N (M, A, Ḳ) and tatobiybN↓ (M, Ḳ) [as inf. ns.] signify The suffering loss, or diminution; or being lost: and perishing, or dying: or [used as substs.] loss, or diminution; or the state of being lost: and perdition, or death: (M,* A, Ḳ:*) and so tabaAbN↓, (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [said to be] a subst. from tab-abahu, with teshdeed, (Mṣb,) and tababN↓ and tabiybN↓: (Ḳ:) or the last three signify [simply] perdition, or death: (M:) and tatobiybN↓ is explained as signifying loss, or diminution, that brings, or leads, to perdition or death; (IAth, TA;) and so tabaAbN↓; (Bḍ in cxi. 1;) and the causing to perish. (T, TA.) Hence you say, tab-a tabaAbFA↓ [meaning, in an emphatic manner, May he suffer loss, or be lost, or perish]. (Ṣ.) And tab-FA lahu May God decree to him loss, or perdition; or cause loss, or perdition, to cleave to him: (Ṣ, M,* Mṣb,* Ḳ:*) tab-FA being in the accus. case as an inf. n. governed by a verb understood. (Ṣ.) And tab-FA tabiybFA↓, [in the CK tatobiybFA,] meaning the same in an intensive, or emphatic, manner: (M, Ḳ:) and tab-FA tabaAbFA↓. (TA.) And tab-ato yadaAhu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and tab-ato yaduhu,, aor. _i {yatobibu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. tab-N and tabaAbN↓, but IDrd says that the former of these seems to be the inf. n., and the latter the simple subst., (M,) May his arms, or hands, and his arm, or hand, suffer loss, or be lost, or perish: (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Bḍ in cxi. 1:) or ‡ may he himself suffer loss,, &c., (Mṣb,* and Bḍ ubi suprà,) i. e., ‡ his whole person: (Jel in cxi. 1:) or ‡ his good in the present life and that in the life to come. (Bḍ ubi suprà.)
[Hence,] tab-a (A, TA) and tabotaba↓ (T, Ḳ) ‡ He became an old man: (T, A, Ḳ:) the loss of youth being likened to tabaAba. (TA.)
tab-a, [aor., accord. to rule, _u,] He cut, or cut off, a thing. (Ḳ.) And tub-a It was cut, or cut off. (TA.)
2. tb-b, inf. n. tatobiybN: see 1, in three places.
tb-bhu (inf. n. as above, Ṣ,) [He caused him to suffer loss, or to become lost: or] he destroyed him, or killed him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He said to him tab-FA: (M, Ḳ:*) [i. e.] he imprecated loss, or perdition, or death, upon him. (A.)

entry.sense: 4. Atb- Qll-ehu quw-atahu ‡ God weakened, or impaired, or may God weaken, or impair, his strength. (Ḳ, TA.)
10. Asttb- ‡ It (a road) became beaten, or trodden, and rendered even, or easy to walk or ride upon, or easy and direct. (A.)

‡ It (an affair) was, or became, rightly disposed or arranged; in a right state: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb:) or it followed a regular, or right, course; was in a right state; and clear, or plain: from musotatib-N applied to a road, explained below: (T, TA:) or it became complete, and in a right state: lit. it demanded loss, or diminution, or destruction; because these sometimes follow completeness: (Ḥar p. 35:) or the b may be a substitute for m; the meaning being Asttm-. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. tabotaba: see 1.
tib-apN A difficult, or distressing, state or condition. (Ḳ.)
tababN: see 1, in several places.
tabaAbN: see 1, in several places.
tabiybN: see 1, in several places.

hom.sense: tab-uwbN i. q. maholakapN [A place of perdition, or destruction; or a desert; or a desert such as is termed mafaAzap]. (Ḳ.)

[It is also said in the Ḳ to signify What the ribs infold: but I think it probable that this meaning has been assigned to it from its having been found erroneously written for tabuwtN, a dial. var. of taAbuwtN.]

entry.sense: taAb-N ‡ An old man; (AZ, T, M, A, Ḳ;) fem. with p {taAb-apN}: (AZ, T, M, A:) and † weak: pl. OatobaAbN: of the dial. of Hudheyl; and extr. [with respect to analogy]. (M.) You say, kunotu XaAb-FA faSirotu taAb-FA [I was a young man, and I have become an old man]. (A.) And OaXaAb-apN Oanoti Oamo taAb-apN [Art thou a young woman or an old woman?] (A.)
Also, (T, Ḳ,) or taAb-u AlZ-ahori, (T,) † An ass, and a camel, having galls, or sores, on his back: (T, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
[See also baAt-N.]

musotatib-N, applied to a road, ‡ Furrowed by passengers, so that it is manifest to him who travels along it; and to this is likened an affair that is clear, or plain, and in a right state. (T.) [See the verb, 10.]
tabuwtN i. q. taAbuwtN; (Ḳ;) a dial. var. of the latter. (TA.) See both in art. twb.

hom.sense: 1. tabira, aor. _a {yatobaru}, (Lth, T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tabaArN; (Lth, T, M;) and tabara, aor. _u {yatoburu}; (Mṣb;) He, or it, (a thing, Lth, T, M,) perished. (Lth, T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: 2. tb-rhu, inf. n. tatobiyrN; (Zj, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) and tabarahu↓, aor. _i {yatobiru}, inf. n. taborN; (Ḳ;) He broke it: (Ḳ:) or he broke it in pieces; (Ṣ, M;) and did away with it: (M:) or he crumbled it, or broke it into small pieces, with his fingers: (Zj, T:) and he destroyed it: (Zj, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) He (God) destroyed him. (A.)

[tiborN a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p {tiborapN}: Native gold, in the form of dust or of nuggets: this is the sense in which the word is generally used in the present day:] broken gold: (M:) it is not so called unless in the dust of its mine, or broken: (IJ, M:) or gold, and silver, before it is wrought: (Lth, T, IF, Mṣb:) or broken, or crumbled, particles of gold, and of silver, before they are wrought: when they are wrought, they are called cahabN and fiD-apN: (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) or uncoined gold (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) and silver: (Mgh:) when coined, it is called EayonN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) [properly,] the term tbr should not be employed save as applied to gold; but some apply it to silver also: (Ṣ:) the tbr of silver, as well as of gold, is mentioned in a trad.: (TA:) or gold (M, Ḳ) universally: (M:) and silver: (Ḳ:) or what is extracted from the mine, (M, Ḳ,) of gold and silver and all jawaAhir [here meaning native ores] of the earth, (M,) before it is wrought (M, Ḳ) and used: (M:) or any jawohar [or native ore] before it is used, of copper (Zj, T, Mgh, Mṣb) and brass (Zj, T, Mgh) or iron (Mṣb) &c.: (Zj, Mgh, Mṣb:) and any jwhr [or native ore] that is used, of copper and brass: (Ḳ:) the word is sometimes applied to other minerals than gold and silver, as copper and iron and lead, but generally to gold; and some say that its primary application is to gold, and that the other applications are later, or tropical: (TA:) also broken pieces of glass. (Zj, T, M, Ḳ.)
tiboriyapN a dial. var. of hiboriyapN, (AO, Ṣ,) i. e. [Scurf on the head;] what is formed at the roots of the hair, like bran. (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
tabaArN Destruction, or perdition: (Zj, T, Ṣ, M, &c.:) inf. n. of tabira. (Lth, T, M.)
mutab-arN Broken up [and] destroyed: so in [the saying in the Ḳur vii. 135,] heWulaMCi mutab-arN maA humo fiyhi [As to these people, that wherein they are shall be broken up and destroyed]. (Ṣ.)
raOoIN mutab-arN Counsel destroyed, or brought to nought. (TA, from a trad.)
matobuwrN [Destroyed;] in a state of destruction: (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) and defective, or deficient. (IAạr, T.)

1. tabiEahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yatobaEu}, inf. n. tabaEN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tabaAEapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He followed; or went, or walked, behind, or after; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) him, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or it; namely, a people, or company of men: (Ṣ:) or [in the CK “and”] he went with him, or it, when the latter had passed by him: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and Ait-abaEahu↓ signifies the same; (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ *) and so does OatobaEahu↓: (Lth, Mgh, Ḳ:) or OatobaEotuhumo↓ signifies I overtook them, they having gone before me; (Fr,* AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also tabiEotuhumo: (Fr, Ḳ:) Akh says that tabiEotuhu and OatobaEotuhu↓ signify the same: and hence the saying in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 10], faOatobaEahu↓ XihaAbN vaAqibN [and a shooting star piercing the darkness by its light overtaketh him]: (Ṣ:) and the saying in the same [vii. 174], faOatobaEahu↓ AlX-ayoTaAnu and the devil overtook him: (TA:)
and the saying in the same [xx. 81], faOatobaEahumo↓ firoEawonu bijunuwdihi and Pharaoh overtook them with his troops: or almost did so: (Ibn-ʼArafeh, Ḳ:) or this signifies made his troops to follow them; (TA;) the b, accord. to some, being redundant: (Bḍ:) or OatobaEahu↓ signifies he followed his footsteps; and sought him, following him: (TA:) but Ait-abaEahumo↓ signifies he went [after them, or followed them,] when they had passed by him; as also tabiEahumo, inf. n. tabaEN: you say, maA zilotu Oat-abiEuhumo↓ Hat-aI OatobaEotuhumo↓, i. e. [I ceased not to follow them] until I overtook them: (AʼObeyd:) Fr says that OatobaEa↓ is better than Ait-abaEa↓; for the latter signifies he went behind, or after, him, when the latter person was going along; but when you say, OatobaEotuhu↓, it is as though [you meant that] you followed his footsteps: (TA:) and Ait-abaEa↓ fulaAnN fulaAnFA↓ [as in the L and TA, but perhaps a mistake for OatobaEa↓,] signifies also he followed him, desiring to do evil to him; like as Pharaoh followed Moses: (L, TA:) some say, tabiEotu AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. tubuwEN, meaning I went after the thing: and tabiEa AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. tabaEN and tabaAEN, † [he followed the thing] in respect of actions: (L, TA:) you say, tabiEa AlUimaAma † he followed the Imám [by doing as he did]: (Mṣb:) [but in this last sense, more commonly,] one says, Ait-abaEahu↓, meaning † he did like as he [another] did: (TA:) and Ait-abaEa↓ AlquroMna † he followed the Kurán as his guide; did according to what is in it: (TA:) and you say also, taAbaEahu↓ EalaI AlOamori; (Mṣb;) or ElI kacaA, inf. n. mutaAbaEapN and tibaAEN; (Ṣ;) † [he followed him, or imitated him, in the affair;] (Mṣb;) he followed him, or imitated him, in doing such a thing: (PṢ:) [but this last phrase has another meaning: see 3.] In the saying, laA yutobaEu binaArK UilaI Alqabori, [in which the verb may be pass. of tabiEa or of OatobaEa↓,] or, accord. to one relation, lA yut-abaEu↓, each in the pass. form, [Fire shall not be made to follow to the grave, though it may be rendered one shall not follow with fire to the grave, it is said that] the b is to render the verb transitive. (Mgh.)

tabiEa, of which the aor., yatobaE, occurs in a trad., [see 4,] (Mgh, TA,) pronounced by the relaters of trads. with teshdeed, [yat-abiE↓,] (TA,) also signifies † He accepted a reference from his debtor to another for the payment of what was owed to him. (Mgh, TA.*)

hom.sense: 2. tab-aEa Qll-ehu lifulaAnK, inf. n. tatobiyEN, May God make a thing to be followed by another thing to such a one, is said in relation to good and to evil; like sab-aEa lahu. (TA in art. sbE.)
See also 5.

entry.sense: 3. tibaAEN [and mutaAbaEapN, the inf. ns. of taAbaEa,] i. q. wilaMCN [The making a consecution, or succession, of one to the other, bayona Oamorayoni between two things, or affairs: and the making consecutive, successive, or uninterrupted, in its progressions, or gradations, or the like: see 6]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., taAbiEuwA bayona AlHaj-i wAlEumorapi [Make ye a consecution between the Hj- and the Emrp; meaning make ye the performance of the Hj- and that of the Emrp to be consecutive]; (TA;) i. e. when ye perform the Hj-, then perform ye the Emrp; and when ye perform the Emrp, then perform ye the Hj-: or when ye perform either of these, then perform ye after it the other, without any length of time [intervening]: but the former [meaning] is the more obvious. (Marginal note in a copy of the Jámi'-eṣ-Ṣagheer of Es-Suyootee.) And you say, taAbiEo bayonanaA wabayonahumo EalaI AlxayoraAti † Make thou us to be followers, or imitators, of them in excellencies. (TA.) And tAbE AlOagaAniI-a [He sang songs consecutively, successively, or uninterruptedly]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. jr.) And tAbE UisoqaATahu [He made it to fall, fall down, drop, drop down, or tumble down, in consecutive portions or quantities]. (M and Ḳ in art. sqT: in the CK AasoqATahu.) And tAbE Alfarasu AljaroIa † [The horse prosecuted, or continued, the course, or running, uninterruptedly]. (Ḳ voce halaba;, &c.) And huwa yataAbiEu AlHadiyva ‡ He carries on the narrative, or discourse, by consecutive progressions, or uninterruptedly: or, as Z says, pursues it, or carries it on, well. (TA.) [See also a similar phrase in what here follows.]

tAbE Alqawosa He pared, or trimmed, the bow well, giving to each part thereof what was its due. (Ḳ, TA.) Skr says that the phrase tuwbiEa baroyuhaA, used by Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee in describing a bow, means The paring, or trimming, of which has been executed with uniformity, part after part. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) the saying of Abu-l-Wákid El-Leythee, (Ṣ, TA,) in a trad., (Ṣ,) taAbaEonaA AlOaEomaAla falamo najido XayoYFA Oabolaga fiI Talabi AlMxirapi mina Alz-uhodi fiI Ald-unoyaA (Ṣ, TA) † We have practised works with diligence, and acquired a sound knowledge of them, [and we have not found anything more efficacious in the pursuit of the blessings of the world to come than abstinence in respect of the enjoyments of the present world.] (Ṣ,* TA.) You say also, tAbE Eamalahu, meaning † He made his work sound, or free from defect: (Kr, Ṣ:) and in like manner, kalaAmahu his language, or speech. (Kr.)
[Hence also,] tAbE AlmaroEaI AlUibila ‡ The pasture fattened the camels well and thoroughly. (Ḳ, TA.)
tAbEhu EalaI AlOamori † He aided, assisted, or helped, him to do the thing, or affair. (TA.)
See also 1, where another meaning of the same phrase is mentioned, in the latter half of the paragraph.
taAbaEotuhu biHaq-iI: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

hom.sense: 4. AtbEhu: see 1, from the beginning nearly to the end.

Also He made him to follow; or to overtake: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he made him to be a follower: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or he urged him, or induced him, to be a follower. (Mgh.) You say, [making the verb doubly trans.,] OatobaEotuhumo gayoriI [I made them to follow, or overtake, another, not myself]. (Ḳ.) And OatobaEotuhu AlX-aIoCa fatabiEahu [I made him to follow, or overtake, the thing, and he followed it, or overtook it]. (Ṣ.) And OatobaEotu zayodFA EamorFA I made Zeyd to be a follower of ʼAmr: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or I urged, or induced, Zeyd to be a follower of ʼAmr. (Mgh.) And OatobaEahu nafosahu mutaHas-irFA EalaI maA faAta † [He made his mind, or desire, to follow after it, regretting what had passed away]. (TA in art. Ejz.) [See also 10.] It is said in a prov., (TA,) OatobiEi Alfarasa lijaAmahaA [Make thou its bit and bridle to follow the horse]: or Aln-aAqapa zimaAmahaA [her nose-rein, the she-camel]: or Ald-alowa riXaMCahaA [its rope, the bucket]: used in bidding to complete a favour, or benefaction: (Ḳ, TA:) AʼObeyd says, I think the meaning of the first prov. to be, Thou hast liberally given the horse, and the bit and bridle are a smaller matter; therefore satisfy thou completely the want, seeing that the horse is not without need of the bit and bridle. (TA.)

Hence the trad., mano OutobiEa EalaI maliIoCK faloyatobaEo ‡ Whoso is referred, for the payment of what is owed to him, to a solvent man, let him accept the reference: (Mgh, TA:*) [see also 1, last meaning:] the verb being made trans. by means of ElI because it conveys the meaning of UiHaAlapN. (Mgh.) You say [also], OutobiEa fulaAnN bifulaAnK ‡ Such a one was referred, for the payment of what was owed to him, to such a one. (Ṣ, TA.) And OatobaEahu Ealayohi ‡ He referred him, for the payment of what was owed to him, to him. (TA.)
[See also UitobaAEN, below.]

entry.sense:
5. ttb-Ehu, inf. n. tatab-uEN, (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) for which Ait-ibaAEN↓ is used by El-Kutámee, tropically, (Ṣ,) or, accord. to Sb, because the same in meaning; (TA;) and tbE-h↓, inf. n. tatobiyEN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) He pursued it; investigated it; examined it; hunted after it; prosecuted a search after it; made successive, or repeated, endeavours to attain it, to reach it, or to obtain it; or sought it, sought for it, or sought after it, successively, time after time, or repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, by degrees, gradually, step by step, bit by bit, or one thing after another, (Lth, Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) following after it. (Ṣ.) Hence the saying of Zeyd Ibn-Thábit, respecting the collecting of the Ḳur-án, faEaliqotu Oatatab-aEuhu mina All-ixaAfi waAlEusubi [And I set myself to seeking to collect it successively,, &c., from the thin white stones and the leafless palm-branches upon which it was written]. (TA.) And ttb-E AlbilaAda yaxoruju mino OaroDK UilaI OaroDK [He investigated the countries, going forth from land to land]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. qrI.) And fulaAnN yatatab-aEu Oavara fulaAnK [Such a one pursues,, &c., the track of such a one]. (TA.) And yatatab-aEu masaAwiIa fulaAnK [He seeks successively,, &c., to discover the vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, of such a one]. (TA.) And yatatab-aEu madaAq-a AlOumuwri wanaHowa celika [He pursues small, or little, affairs; and the like thereof: or he seeks successively,, &c., to obtain a knowledge of the subtilties, niceties, abstrusities, or obscurities, of things, or affairs; and the like thereof]. (TA.)
And ttb-E AlHabola [He took successive holds of the rope]: said of a man descending from a part of a mountain such as is termed Xiyq, by means of a rope tied to that part, to a place in which honey was deposited. (TA in art. Xyq.)

6. ttAbE It was, or became, consecutive, successive, or uninterrupted, in its progressions, or gradations, or the like; syn. tawaAlaI. (Ḳ.) You say, ttAbE suquwTuhu [Its falling, falling down, dropping, dropping down, or tumbling down, was, or became, consecutive,, &c.; i. e. it fell, fell down,, &c., in consecutive portions or quantities]. (M and Ḳ in art. sqT.) And ttAbE Alqawomu The people, or company of men, followed one another. (Mṣb.) And tataAbaEati AlOaXoyaMCu, and AlOamoTaAru, and AlOumuwru, The things, and the rains, and the events, came one after another, each following near upon another. (Lth.) And it is said in a trad., tataAbaEato EalaI qurayoXK sinuw jadobK [Years of dearth, drought, or sterility, came consecutively upon Kureysh]. (TA.)
ttAbE Alfarasu ‡ The horse ran evenly, not raising one of his limbs [above its fellow]. (TA.)
ttAbEt AlUibilu ‡ The camels became fat and goodly. (TA.)
8: see 1, throughout: and see also 5.
10. AsttbEhu He desired, or demanded, of him that he should follow him: (TA:) or he made him to follow him. (L.) [See also 4.]

tiboEN A follower of women: (Lḥ,* Az:) or a passionate lover, and follower, of a woman, (Ḳ,) whithersoever she goes: (TA:) and with p {tiboEapN}, of a man: (Lḥ:) and tub-aEN↓ a sedulous seeker of women. (Ḳ.) [See taAbiEN.] You say also, huwa tiboEu Dil-apK, meaning He is a follower of women: and tiboEu Dil-apN one in whom is no good, and with whom is no good: or, accord. to Th, you only say tiboEu Dil-apK. (TA.)
hecaA tiboEu hecaA This is what follows this. (M in art. tlw.)
See also tabiyEN, in two places.
tabaEN: see taAbiEN, in six places.
rajulN tubaEN lilokalaAmi A man who makes his speech consecutive, one part to another. (Yoo, Ḳ.*)
baqarapN taboEaI A cow desiring [and therefore following] the bull. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

tabiEapN and tibaAEapN↓ signify the same; (T, Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ;) [The consequence of an action: and] a claim which one seeks to obtain for an injury, or injurious treatment, and the like: (T, O, L, Ḳ; and so the Mṣb in explanation of the former word:) the former is also explained as signifying a right, or due, annexed to property, claimed from the possessor of the property: (L:) pl. [of the former] tabiEaAtN and [of the latter] tibaAEaAtN. (TA.) A poet says,
Oakalato Haniyfapu rab-ahaA
zamana Alt-aqaH-umi waAlmajaAEaho
lamo yaHocaruwA mino rab-ihimo
suwoCa AlEawaAqibi waAlt-ibaAEaho↓
[Ḥaneefeh ate their lord, in the time of experiencing dearth, or drought, or sterility, and hunger: they did not fear, from their lord, the evil of the results, and the consequence of their action]: for they had taken to themselves a god consisting of Hayos, [i. e. dates mixed with clarified butter and the preparation of milk called OaqiT, kneaded together,] and worshipped it for some time; then famine befell them, and they ate it. (Ṣ.) And one says, maA Ealayohi mina Qll-ehi fiI hecaA tabiEapN, and tibaAEapN↓, There is not, against him, on the part of God, in this, any claim on account of wrong-doing. (TA.)

hom.sense: tabiyEN [One who is prosecuted, or sued, for a right, or due; of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, from tabiEotuhu biHaq-iI;] one who owes property to another, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and whom the latter prosecutes, or sues, for it. (TA.)

The young one of a cow in the first year; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) so says Aboo-Fak'as El-Asadee: (TA:) or that is a year old; (Az, Mgh, TA;) not so called until he has completed the year; erroneously said by Lth to signify a calf ripening to his perfect state: (Az, TA:) thus called because he yet follows his mother; (Mgh, Mṣb;) the word in this sense being of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Mṣb:) and tiboEN↓ signifies the same: (TA:) fem. of the former with p {tabiyEapN}: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. tibaAEN and tabaAYiEN; (AA, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) both pls. of tabiyEN; (AA, Ṣ, O;) or the former is pl. of tabiyEapN; (Mṣb;) and the pl. of tabiyEN is OatobiEapN [a pl. of pauc.]; (L, Mṣb;) and OataAbiEu and OataAbiyEu, the latter of which is extr., are pls. of OatobiEapN: (L:) the pl. of tiboEN↓ in the abovementioned sense is OatobaAEN. (TA.) Accord. to EshShaabee, (IF,) One whose horns and ears are equal [in length]: (IF, Ḳ:) but this is a judicial explanation; not deduced from the rules of lexicology. (IF.)

I. q. taAbiEN↓ [as signifying One who prosecutes, or sues, for a right, or due; and particularly for blood-revenge]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying in the Ḳur [xvii. 71], vum-a laA tajiduwA lakumo EalayonaA bihi tabiyEFA Then ye shall not find for you any to prosecute for blood-revenge, nor any to sue, against us therein: (Fr. Ṣ, Ḳ:) or ye shall not find for you any to sue us for the disallowing of what hath befallen you, nor for our averting it from you: (Zj:) [or any aider against us; for] tabiyEN also signifies an aider; and especially against an enemy. (Lth, Ḳ.)
See also taAbiEN, latter half.

entry.sense: tibaAEapN: see tabiEapN, in three places.

tub-aEN An appellation of each of the Kings of El-Yemen (Ṣ, Ḳ) who possessed Himyer and Hadramowt, (Ḳ, TA,) and, as some add, Sebà; (TA;) but not otherwise; (Ḳ, TA;) and the like of this is said in the ʼEyn: (TA:) so called because they followed one another; whenever one died, another took his place, following him in his course of acting: (TA:) pl. tabaAbiEapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with p added as having the meaning of a rel. n.; [as though it were pl. of tub-aEiI-N, like as HanaAbilapN is pl. of HanobaliI-N;] erroneously written in some of the copies of the Ḳ ttAbEp: (TA:) the tbAbEp of Himyer were like the OakaAsirap of the Persians and the qayaASirap of the Romans. (Lth.) In the Ḳur xliv. 36, it is said in a trad. to mean a particular king, who was a believer, and whose people were unbelievers. (Zj.)

And hence, (TA,) A species of the yaEaAsiyb [or kings of the bees], (Ḳ,) the greatest and most beautiful thereof, whom the other bees follow: (TA:) pl. tabaAbiyEu; (Ḳ;) in the L, tataAbiEu [which is probably a mistranscription for tabaAbiEu]. (TA.)
A species of Tayor [which means any flying things, as well as birds; and may therefore, perhaps, be meant to indicate what next precedes]. (Ṣ.)

The shade, or shadow; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because it follows the sun; as also tub-uEN↓. (Ḳ.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, Soadà El-Juhaneeyeh, (TA,) or Selmà El-Juhaneeyeh, (marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ,) bewailing her brother, As'ad,
yaridu AlmiyaAhu HaDiyrapN wanafiyDapF
wiroda AlqaTaApi UicaA QsomaOal-a Alt-ub-aEu , (Ṣ) [He comes to the waters when people are dwelling, or staying, there, (but see HaDiyrapN,) and when no one is there, as the bird called katáh comes to water] when the shade has become contracted at mid-day: or, accord. to Aboo-Leylà, the meaning is, the shade of night; i. e., this man comes to the waters in the last part of the night, before any one: though it means also the shade of day-time: (TA:) or, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer, the meaning here is [the star, or asterism, called] Ald-abaraAn; and this is very probably correct; for the bird above mentioned comes to the waters by night, and seldom by day; and hence the saying, Oadal-u mino qaTaApK. (Az, TA.) See taAbiEN.
See also tiboEN.
maA OadoriI OaI-u tub-aEK huwa I know not who of men he is. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
tub-aEN is also a pl. of taAbiEN [q. v.]. (TA.)
tub-uEN: see tub-aEN.

tab-uwEu AlX-amosi A certain wind, (Ḳ, TA,) also called Aln-ukayobaMCu, (TA,) which blows (Ḳ, TA) in the early morning, (TA,) with the rising of the sun, (Ḳ, TA,) from the direction of the wind called AlS-abaA, unaccompanied by rising clouds, (TA,) and veers round through the various places whence winds blow until it returns to the place from which blows the wind called AlSbA, (Ḳ, TA,) whence it commenced in the early morning: (TA:) the Arabs dislike it. (Z, TA.)

taAbiEN Following; a follower: (TA:) and tabaEN↓ also signifies the same as taAbiEN; (Ḳ;) a thing that follows in the track of a thing; (Lth, Az;) or that is at the kinder, or latter, part of anything; (TA;) but is used alike as sing. and pl.: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the pl. of taAbiEN is tub-aEN and tub-aAEN (TA) [and, applied to rational beings, taAbiEuwna]: and the pl. of tabaEN↓ is OatobaAEN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or this may be used as a pl. of tabaEN; (Mṣb;)
or it is pl. of taAbiEN, like as xadamN is pl. of xaAdimN, (Kr, Mgh,) and TalabN of TaAlibN, &c.; (Ḳ;) or, correctly speaking, it is a quasi-pl. n. (Sb, TA.) You say, AlmuSal-iI tabaEN↓ lAimaAmihi [The person praying is a follower of his Imám]: and Aln-aAsu tabaEN lahu [The people are followers of him]. (Mṣb.) And it is said in the Ḳur [xiv. 24, and xl. 50], Uin-aA kun-aA lakumo tabaEFA↓ [Verily we were followers of you]: (Ṣ, TA:) in which the last word may be a quasi-pl. n. of taAbiEN; or it may be an inf. n., meaning cawiI tabaEK. (TA.) tabaEN↓ is applied as an epithet to the legs of a beast: (Lth, T:) and is also used as [an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] signifying The legs of a beast. (Ḳ.)

A jinnee, or genie, that accompanies a woman and follows her whithersoever she goes, (Ḳ, TA,) loving her: (TA:) and taAbiEapN a jinneeyeh, or female genie, that does the same to a man: (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA:) or the p is added in the latter to give intensiveness to the signification, or to denote evilness of nature, or to convey the meaning of daAhiyapN, q. v.: the pl. is tawaAbiEu: and this means female associates. (TA.)
See also tabiyEN.
[Also One next in the order of time after the SaHaAbap; like taAbiEiI-N↓.]
[And in grammar, An appositive.]

taAbiEu Aln-ajomi [The follower of the asterism; i. e., of the Pleiades;] a name of Ald-abaraAn [the Hyades; or the five chief stars thereof; or the brightest star among them, a of Taurus]: this name being given to it as ominous of good; (Ḳ;) or as ominous of evil: (O:) or so called because it follows the Pleiades: (T:) also called Alt-aAbiEu, (T in art. dbr, Sh, IB, and others,) and tuwayobiEN↓, (Ḳ,) which is the dim., (TA,) or Alt-uwayobiEu, (T in art. dbr,) and tub-aEN↓, (Ḳ,) or Alt-ub-aEu [q. v.], (Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer, T,) and Alt-abaEu↓, (IB, Z,) and Alt-aAliI, and AlHaAdiI, (IB,) or HAdI Aln-ujuwmi, (Ṣ in art. jdH,) or HAdI Aln-ajomi. (Ḳzw and others.) [See also AlmijodaHu.] taAbiEiI-N: see taAbiEN.
tuwayobiEN: see taAbiEN, last sentence.

UitobaAEN in language is when one says the like of HasanN basanN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and qabiyHN XaqiyHN: (Ṣ:) The putting, after a word, an imitative sequent, i. e. another word similar to the former in measure or in its rawiI-, by way of pleonasm, or for fulness of expression, and for corroboration; (Mz 28th nwE, and Kull p. 11;) the latter word being one not used alone, and having no meaning by itself, as in HasanN basanN; or being one which has a meaning of its own, as in haniyoYFA mariyoYFA. (Kull ubi suprà.)
[Also The latter of such two words; i. e. an imitative sequent.]

[And used in the former sense, as an inf. n., it denotes various other kinds of assimilation, i. e., of one word to another preceding or following it, and of one vowel to another preceding or following it in the same word.]

mutobiEN She who has with her children, or young ones: (Lḥ:) or a ewe, or she-goat, and a cow, and a girl, having her offspring following her: (Ḳ:) or a cow having a tabiyE, q. v.: and IB mentions also mutobiEapN as signifying the same: and a female servant followed by her offspring whither she comes and goes. (TA.)
matobuwEN [pass. part. n. of 1.]
[In grammar, The antecedent of a taAbiE, i. e., of an appositive.]
mutaAbaEN † Anything made, or executed, soundly, thoroughly, well, or so as to be free from defect. (Ḳ,* TA.)

mutataAbiEN Consecutive, successive, or uninterrupted, in its progressions, or gradations, or the like. (TA.) You say luWoluWN mutataAbiEN Pearls following one another, or doing so in uninterrupted order. (TA.) And SiyaAmu Xahorayoni mutataAbiEayoni The fasting of two consecutive months. (TA.)

guSonN mutataAbiEN ‡ An even, or a uniform, branch, in which are no knots. (Ḳ,* TA.) And farasN mutataAbiEu Alxaloqi ‡ A horse symmetrical in make, (A, Ḳ,) justly proportioned in his limbs or parts. (A, TA.) And rajulN mutataAbiEu AlEilomi ‡ A man whose knowledge is uniform, consistent, without incongruity. (Ḳ,* TA.)

hom.sense: 1. tabalahu, (Lth, T, M,) aor. _i {yatobilu}, (M,) inf. n. tabolN, (Lth, T, M,) He pursued him with enmity, or hostility: (Lth, T:) or he bore enmity, or was hostile, to him. (M.)
tabalahumu Ald-ahoru, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tabolN, (M,) ‡ Time, or fortune, smote them with its vicissitudes, (M, Ḳ,) and (Ḳ) destroyed them; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Oatobalahumo↓. (Ṣ, TA.)

tabalahu AlHub-u, (Ṣ, M,) or AlhawaI, (T,) aor. _i {yatobilu}, (M,) inf. n. tabolN; (T, Ḳ;) and Atblhu↓, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. UitobaAlN; (Ḳ, TA;) Love made him sick, or ill; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ; [in the CK, wAlAasoqaAmu kAlAatobaAli is erroneously put for wAlUisoqaAmu kAlUitobaAli;]) and caused him to be in a bad, or unsound, state: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, tabalahu signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (Ḳ,) it took away his reason, (M, Ḳ,) and bewildered him. (TA.)
You say also, of a woman, tabalato fuWaAda Alr-ajuli, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, as though meaning, (M,) She smote the man's heart with tabol↓ [app. meaning love-sickness]. (M, Ḳ.)
See also Q. Q. 1.

entry.sense: 2: see Q. Q. 1.
3: see Q. Q. 1.
4. Atblhu, inf. n. UitobaAlN, He made him a victim of blood-revenge, or retaliation of murder or homicide. (Ṣ: the meaning is indicated there, but not expressed.)
See also 1, in two places.

Q. Q. 1. tawobala Alqidora, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and taOobalahaA, with hemz, (IJ, M,) or taAbalahaA↓, [without C,] (Ḳ,) mentioned by Ibn-ʼAbbád in the Moḥeeṭ, (TA,) and tab-alahaA↓, (T, M, Ḳ,) said by Lth to be allowable, (T,) and tabalahaA↓, (Ḳ,) He seasoned [the contents of] the cooking-pot with taAbal; (Mṣb;) he put taAbal into the cooking-pot; (Ḳ;) i. q. qaz-aHahaA and faH-aAhaA: (AʼObeyd, T:) from taAbalN. (Ṣ, M.*)
[Hence,] tawobala kalaAmahu ‡ He seasoned [meaning he embellished] his speech, or language; syn. qaz-aHahu (TA) and baz-arahu. (A in art. bzr.)
tabolN [originally inf. n. of 1, q. v.]

Enmity, or hostility, (Lth, T, M, Ḳ, TA,) in the heart, (TA,) with which one is pursued: (Lth, T:) pl. tubuwlN (Lth, T, M, Ḳ) and tabaAbiylu↓, which latter is extr. (Ḳ.) You say, liI Einodahu tabolN [He has enmity, or hostility, towards me, with which he pursues me]. (T.)

I. q. tirapN (Ṣ) and caHolN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) [by the former of which may be intended the meaning explained above, or, as appears to be meant by the latter, blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide; or prosecution for blood; or a desire of, or seeking for, retaliation of a crime or of enmity]: pl. tubuwlN. (Ṣ.) Alt-abolu as meaning Alc-aHolu is likened by Yezeed Ibn-El-Hakam Eth-Thakafee to a debt which one should be paid. (Ḥam p. 530.) And one says, OuSiyba bitabolK [He was made a victim of blood-revenge, or retaliation of murder or homicide: or, perhaps, of enmity, or hostility]. (Ṣ.) And bayonahumo tubuwlN [Between them are blood-revenges,, &c.]. (TA.)
Love-sickness. (Kull p. 167. [See Hub-u.]) See 1.

dahorN tabila, (M,) or taAbilN↓, (TA,) ‡ Time, or fortune, that smites people with its vicissitudes, (M, TA,) and destroys them. (TA.) And dahorN mutobilN↓ xabilN, occurring in a poem of El-Aạshà, † Time, or fortune, that destroys, or carries off, family and children. (Ṣ.)
tabiylN: see matobuwlN.
tabaAbiylu: see tabolN.
tab-aAlN A possessor [or seller] of tawaAbil pl. of taAbalN. (Ḳ.)

taAbalN, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) also pronounced taOobalN, with C, (IJ, M,) and taAbilN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and tawobalu↓, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) Seeds (OabozaArN Mṣb and Ḳ) that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; (T, Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. q. faHFA; (T, M;) such as cumin-seeds and coriander-seeds: (TA voce qizoHN:) said to be arabicized: Ibn-El-Jawá- leekee says that the vulgar distinguish between tAbl and AbzAr, [in the manner explained voce bizorN,] but the [classical] Arabs do not: (Mṣb:) pl. tawaAbilu. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: taAbilN: see tabilN:
and see taAbalN.

entry.sense: tawobalu: see taAbalN.

tuwbaAlN [from the Persian tuwbaAlo or tuwPaAlo?] What falls in consecutive portions, or particles, on the occasion of the hammering of copper and of iron: a mivoqaAl thereof, with hydromel, drunk, powerfully alleviates the [ejection of] phlegm. (Ḳ.)
mutobilN: see tabilN.
matobuwlN A man rendered love-sick; (T;) as also tabiylN↓: (M:) and the former, a lover who is not granted that which he wants. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. tabana, aor. _i {yatobinu}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tabonN, (Ṣ,) He fed a beast with tibon [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
Also He sold [tibon, i. e.] straw. (KL.)

tabina, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yatobanu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tabanN, (T, Ṣ,) or tabonN, (M, Ḳ,) and tabaAnapN (T, Ṣ,* M, Ḳ) and tabaAniyapN, (M,) He was, or became, intelligent, sagacious, skilful, or knowing; syn. faTina, (Ḳ,) or SaAra faTinFA; (Ṣ;) and nice, or minute, in inspection (Ṣ, Ḳ) into affairs: (Ṣ:) or tabaAnapN signifies the being very intelligent or sagacious or skilful or knowing, and nice, or minute, in inspection; as also TabaAnahN; accord. to AO and AA: (T:) these two words signify the same (T, Ṣ, M *) accord. to [most of] the leading authorities: (T:) and Yaạḳoob asserts that the t is a substitute for T: (M:) [or the reverse seems to be the case in the opinion of Az, who here remarks that there are many instances of the change of t into T:] or the former is in evil; and the latter, in good: (M:) or, accord. to Lth, Tabina means in evil; and tabina, in good; so that he makes TbAnp to be in deceiving, or beguiling, and suddenly, or unexpectedly, attacking or destroying: but En-Naḍr says the contr.; and accord. to him, TabanN signifies the having knowledge of affairs, and intelligence, or sagacity, and science: (T:) and tb-n↓, inf. n. tatobiynN signifies the same as tabina: (Ḳ:) or he inspected nicely, or minutely: as in a trad. in which it is said, respecting a woman whose husband has died leaving her pregnant, yunofaqu EalayohaA mino jamiyEi AlmaAli Hat-aI tab-anotumo maA tab-anotumo, meaning [She shall be expended upon from the whole of the property] until ye make a nice, or minute, inspection [into the circumstances of the case], and say otherwise, (T, Ṣ,) i. e., that she shall be expended upon from her own share: (T:) and so in another trad., in which it is said, Uin-a Alr-ajula layatakal-amu biAlkalimapi yutab-inu fiyhaA yahowiI bihaA fiI Aln-aAri, (AʼObeyd, T, M,) i. e. [Verily a man will say a saying] in which he will be nice, or minute [in expression, whereby he will fall into the fire of Hell]: (TA:) here AʼObeyd thinks the meaning to be the making language obscure, or abstruse, and disputing in a matter of religion. (T.) You say also, tabina lahu (T, M, TA) He understood it; or knew it; or had knowledge, or was cognizant, of it; (TA;) i. q. Tabina. (M.)
2. tb-n, inf. n. tatobiynN: see 1.
tabon-hu, inf. n. as before, He clad him with a tub-aAn. (TA.)

entry.sense: 8. Ait-abana He clad himself with a tub-aAn. (Ḳ.)
tabonN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: tibonN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and tabonN↓ (M, Ḳ) Straw; i. e. the stalks, or stems, (EaSiyf, M, Ḳ,) or the stalk, or stem, (saAq, Mṣb,) of seed-produce, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) such as wheat and the like, (M, Ḳ,) [generally] after it has been trodden or thrashed [and cut]; (Mṣb;) wheat when it has been trodden or thrashed [and cut] by the feet of beasts or by repeatedly drawing over it the [machine called] midowas [q. v.]: (Mgh in art. dws:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {tibonapN} [signifying a straw, or piece of straw]. (Ṣ, M.) You say Oaqal-u mino tibonapK [Less than a straw, or piece of straw]. (TA.)

Also, the former, A great bowl: (Ṣ:) or a bowl that satisfies the thirst of twenty: (Ḳ:) or the greatest of bowls, that almost satisfies the thirst of twenty: (Ks, Ṣ, M:) next is the SaHon, which is nearly equal thereto: then, the Eus-, that satisfies the thirst of three and of four: then, the qadaH, that satisfies the thirst of two men: then, the qaEob, that satisfies the thirst of one man: then, the gumar: (Ks, Ṣ:) or a bowl of rude, or rough, make; not made neatly, or skilfully. (M.)
[Hence, probably,] † A liberal, or bountiful, and noble, chief. (Ḳ.)
And A wolf. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: tabinN Intelligent, sagacious, skilful, or knowing; and nice, or minute, in inspection (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) into affairs; (Ṣ;) as also TabinN: (M:) [or very intelligent,, &c.: and accord. to some, in evil: or in good: see tabina.]
And One who plays with his hand with everything. (Ḳ.)

tab-aAnN A seller of tibon: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) thus, perfectly decl., if of the measure faE-aAl, from Alt-ibonu: but if of the measure faEolaAn, from Alt-ab-u [the act of cutting (for tibon is generally cut by the thrashingmachine)], it is [tab-aAnu,] imperfectly decl. (Ṣ.)

tub-aAnN Small saraAwiyl [or breeches], (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) without legs, [i. e. having only two holes through which to put the legs,] (TA in art. vfr,) [made of linen, and of leather,] of the measure of a span, (Ṣ, Mgh,) such as to conceal the anterior and posterior pudenda (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA) only; (TA;) worn by sailors (Ṣ, Mgh) [and by wrestlers]: or a thing like srAwyl: (M, Mṣb:) or a thing like small srAwyl: (T:) [it is an arabicized word, from the Persian tunobaAnN:] the Arabs make it masc. (T, M, Mṣb) and fem.: (Mṣb:) pl. tabaAbiynu. (T, Mṣb.)
tab-aAnapN (TA) and matobanapN↓ (Mgh, Mṣb, TA) and matobanN↓ (Mgh, Mṣb) The place, (TA,) or house, or the like, (Mgh, Mṣb,) of [or for] tibon. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA.)
matobanN: see tab-aAnapN.
matobanapN: see tab-aAnapN.
matobuwnN, applied to a horse such as is termed birocawn, Of the colour of tibon [or straw]. (TA.)
taAbuwhN a dial. var. of taAbuwtN, of the dial. of the Ansár. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. twb, q. v.)
taAbuwtN: see art. twb. Accord. to some, it belongs to the present art., and was originally taAbuwapN.

Alt-ataru [and Alt-ataAru and AltaAtaAru] A certain people, or nation, (Ḳ,) [called by us the Tartars,] in the furthest countries of the East, in the mountains of TgmAj, on the confines of China, (TA,) bordering upon the Turks, (Ḳ,) more than six months' journey from Má-waráä-n-nahr: so in the Murooj edh-Dhahab. (TA.)
tatoraI and tatorFI: see art. wtr.

1. tajara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yatojuru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. tajorN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tijaArapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) or quasi-inf. n., (Mgh,) and matojarN; (A;) and Ait-ajara↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure AifotaEala; (Ṣ;) He practised traffic, merchandise, or commerce; trafficked; traded; dealt; sold and bought; (Ḳ;) employed property for the purpose of gain. (A.) You say, tajara tijaArapF raAbiHapF [He practised a profitable, or lucrative, traffic]. (A.) And fulaAnN yat-ajiru↓ fiI Albar-i waAlbaHori [Such a one traffics on land and sea]. (A.) There can hardly, if at all, be found any other instance of t immediately followed by j except ntj and rtj: the t in tujaAha is originally w. (Mṣb.)
3. tAjrhu, (A,) inf. n. mutaAjarapN, (A, KL,) He practised with him [and (as is implied in the A) he vied with him in practising] traffic, or selling and buying. (KL.)

hom.sense: 8. Ait-ajara: see 1, in two places.
See also 8 in art. wjr.

entry.sense: tajorN: see taAjirN.
Alt-ajiru: see taAjirN.

tijaArapN a subst. from 1; (Mṣb;) or quasi-inf. n.; (Mgh;) [The practice of traffic, merchandise, or commerce; traffic; trade; selling and buying;] the trade of the taAjir, i. e., of him who sells and buys for gain; (Ksh in ii. 15;) the seeking of gain by selling and buying. (Bḍ ibid.) [See also 1.]

Also Merchandise, meaning what is sold and bought, of goods, or commodities, or householdfurniture, and the like; a quasi-inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n. (Mgh.) [Hence the saying,] Ealayokumo bitijaArapi AlMxirapi ‡ [Keep ye to the merchandise of the life to come]. (A.)

taAjirN A merchant; one who practises traffic, merchandise, or commerce; a trafficker; a trader, or tradesman; a dealer; one who sells and buys; (Ḳ;) one who sells and buys for gain: (Ksh in ii. 15:) and a vintner, or seller of wine, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) was also called thus by the Arabs: (Ṣ:) accord. to IAth, this latter is said to be the primary signification: and hence the saying in a trad., Uin-a Alt-aAjira faAjirN [Verily the vintner is a transgressor]: (TA:) pl. tuj-aArN and tijaArN and tajorN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or rather this last is a quasi-pl. n.,] like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and tujurN, (Ḳ,) or this may be a pl. of tijaArN. (ISd, TA.)
Alt-ajiru↓, occurring in a verse of El-Akhtal, [for Alt-aAjiru,] is thought by ISd to be like TahirN [for TaAhirN]. (TA.)
[Hence,] ‡ A man skilful in an affair. (Ḳ, TA.) The Arabs say, Uin-ahu lataAjirN bicelika AlOamori ‡ Verily he is skilful in that affair. (IAạr, TA.)

And ‡ A she-camel that is saleable, or easy of sale, or in much demand, in traffic, and in the market; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also taAjirapN: (Ḳ:) or the latter, a she-camel that is goodly, and saleable, or in much demand: (A:) or that is easy of sale when offered, by reason of her excellence: (T:) or simply, that is easy of sale, or in much demand: (Ṣ:) as though, by reason of her beauty, or goodliness, and fatness, she sold herself: (Ksh in ii. 15:) contr. of kaAsidapN: (Ṣ,* TA:) the pl. of tAjrp is tawaAjiru. (T, A.) You say also, Ealayoka biAls-ilaEi Alt-awaAjiri ‡ [Keep thou to the commodities] that are saleable, or in much demand. (A.) And huwa EalaI Oakorami taAjirapK † He is upon a most noble horse. (Ḳ.)

OaroDN mutojarapN [in the TA, matojirapN, but this is wrong,] A land in which traffic, merchandise, or commerce, is practised; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and to which people go for the purpose of practising the same: (Ḳ:) pl. mataAjiru. (TA.)

1. tajaha, aor. _a {yatojahu}, (AZ, Ḳ, art. wjh,) inf. n. tajohN; (AZ, TA, in that art.;) or, as Aṣ says, tajuha, with damm; (TA in that art.;) i. q. tawaj-aha and waj-aha (Ḳ in that art.) and Ait-ajaha. (Ḳ in art. tjh.) See art. wjh.

tujaAha (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, in art. wjh) and tijaAha (Ṣ, Ḳ, in that art.) and tajaAha (Ḳ in that art.) i. q. wujaAha, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, in that art.,) which is seldom used; the w being generally changed into t. (Mṣb, ibid.)

taHot is the contr. of fawoq: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and Alt-aHotu [signifying The location that is beneath, below, or under,] is opposed to Alfawoqu, and is used in relation to that which is separate from another thing; AlOasofalu being used in relation to that which is united with [or a part of] another thing. (Kull.) Sometimes, (Ḳ,) taHot is an adv. n., (Mṣb, Ḳ,) having a vague signification, its meaning not being clear unless it is prefixed to another word, as in the phrase hecaA taHota hecaA [This is beneath, below, or under, this]. (Mṣb.) And sometimes, it is a simple noun; (Ḳ;) in which case, [not having the article Al,] it is indecl., with ḍammeh for its termination, (Ḳ, and I’Aḳ p. 204,) provided that the noun to which it should be prefixed is suppressed, and the meaning of this is intended to be understood, but not the word itself; (I’Aḳ ubi suprà;) as in mino taHotu [Beneath, below, or under]; (Ḳ;) and in the saying,
OaqabN mino taHotu EariyDN mino Ealu
[Lean beneath; broad above]: otherwise, it is decl.; (I’Aḳ ibid.;) as in tajoriI mino taHotihaA AlOanohaAru [Rivers running beneath them]; (Ḳur ii. 23, &c.;) i.e., beneath their trees, (Bḍ, Jel,) and their pavilions. (Jel.) [You say also, fulaAnN taHota Oamori fulaAnK † Such a one is under the command, rule, or authority, of such a one. And fulaAnN taHotahu fulaAnapu † Such a one has as his wife such a woman: see an ex. in a verse cited voce UicaA. The dim. is tuHayot↓: you say, hedaA tuHayota hecaA, and mino tuHayoti hecaA, This is a little beneath, below, or under, this.]

Alt-aHotu is also the sing. of Alt-uHuwtu, (IAth, TA,) which latter [in the CK erroneously written Alt-uHutu] signifies The low, base, vile, or ignoble, persons. (A, IAth, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., laA taquwmu Als-aAEapu Hat-aI taZohara Alt-uHuwtu wataholika AlwuEuwlu, i. e. [The hour of resurrection will not come until] the low, or ignoble, persons [shall prevail], and the noble persons [shall perish]: (A, IAth, TA:) or, as some say, until the treasures that are beneath the earth appear. (TA.) And in another trad. it is said that among the signs of the resurrection shall be this: Oano yaEoluw Alt-uHuwtu AlwuEuwla That the weak of mankind shall have ascendency over the strong. (TA.)

taHotaAniI-N [Of, or relating to, the location that is beneath, below, or under; inferior; lower;] rel. n. of taHot, like as fawoqaAniI-N is of fawoq: A and n being very often added in the rel. n. (TA.)
[tuHayot dim. of taHot, q. v.]

4. AtHfhu bihi [He presented him with it; or gave it to him as a tuHofap, q. v.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and AtHfhu tuHofapF [He made a present to him; or gave him a tuHofap; and so AtHfhu alone, as in an ex. cited voce OatofaHa]: (Ḳ, TA:) i. q. OaTorafahu bituHofapK [which properly means He presented him with a novel, or rare, and pleasing present; or a gift not given to any one before; or a gift of which he (the recipient) did not possess the like, and which pleased him]: and Ait-aHafahu↓ signifies the same as OatoHafahu. (TA.)
8. Ait-aHafahu: see above {4}. [Perhaps originally AiwotaHafahu: see what follows.]

tuHofapN and tuHafapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) i. q. bir-N [as meaning A gratuitous gift, or favour; or a bounty, or benefit]; and laTafN [meaning a present; i. e. a thing sent to another in token of courtesy or honour]; (Ḳ;) in some copies of the Ḳ, luTof; (TA;) [i. e.] AltHfp signifies maA OatoHafota bihi Alr-ajula mina Albir-i waAll-aTafi; (Ṣ;) or [simply] maA OatoHafota bihi gayoraka: (Mṣb:) and a Turofap [which properly signifies a gift not given to any one before; or of which the recipient did not possess the like, and which pleases him;] (Ḳ, TA;) of fruit, and of sweet-smelling flowers: (TA:) [it generally means simply a present; or a rare, or pleasing, or rare and pleasing, present:] pl. tuHafN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Accord. to some, it is originally wuHofapN: (Ḳ, TA:) Az says that its t is originally w: (Mṣb:) and tawaH-afa is quasi-pass. of OatoHafahu: (Lth, TA:) so that it should be mentioned in art. wHf: (Ḳ, TA:) being like tuhamapN and tuxamapN, &c. (TA.) It is said in a trad., tuHofapu AlS-aAYimi Ald-uhonu waAlmijomaru [The pleasing present for the faster is oil, and aloes-wood or the like]; i. e., these dispel from him the grievousness and distress occasioned by the fasting. (TA.) And in another, respecting dates, tuHofapu Alkabiyri waSumotapu AlS-agiyri [i. e. The date is the pleasing gift for the big, or full-grown, or old, and the quieter of the little one, or child]. (TA.) And in another, tuHofapu AlmuWomini Almawotu [The boon for the believer is death]. (TA.)
taHiyna: see arts. Hyn and lyt.

1. tax-a, (JK, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yatoxixu}, (JK, L,) inf. n. tuxuwxN, (JK, L, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or tuxuwxapN, (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or both, (TA,) It (dough) became sour: (JK, Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) it became soft by reason of too much water: and in like manner, clay, or mud, so that one could not plaster with it. (L.) Also, said of dough, It became leavened; or mature. (JK.)
4. Atx-hu He made it sour; namely, dough: (JK, Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) he made it soft by putting into it too much water; namely, dough: and in like manner, clay, or mud, so that he could not plaster with it. (L.)
tax-N Sour dough: (JK, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) such as is soft by reason of too much water. (L.)
Also Dregs of sesame-grain from which the oil has been expressed; (JK, L, Ḳ;) also called kusobN. (TA.)
taAx-N Having no desire for food [app. by reason of acidity in the stomach]. (JK, Ḳ.)
taxotN A repository in which clothes are kept; (Ḳ;) [a chest for clothes; a wardrobe: pl. tuxuwtN:] a Persian word sometimes used by the Arabs. (IDrd.)
[The following significations of the word seem to be post-classical.]

[A throne: a seat: a seat of government: a moveable wooden bench, or sofa: all which are Persian. Hence, taxotarawaAnN, from the Persian, A kind of covered litter, like a palanquin, borne by two camels or horses, one before and the other behind, or by two or four mules.]
[So too taxotapN A board, or plank: likewise of Persian origin. Hence the verb tax-ata He boarded, or planked.]
1. taxica, aor. _a {yatoxacu}, inf. n. taxacN and taxocN: see 8 in art. Axc.
8. At-xc: see 8 in art. Axc.
Aisotaxaca, an irregularly formed verb: see 8 in art. Axc.
tixoriySN and tixoriySapN (Lth, Ḳ) dial. vars. of dixoriySN and dixoriySapN, (Lth,) A baniyqap [or gore] of a garment: arabicized words, from tiyriyzo, (Lth, Ḳ,) which is Persian. (Lth.)

1. taxima, [originally waxima,] aor. _a {yatoxamu}, (Mṣb, and Ḳ in art. wxm,) inf. n. taxamN; (Mṣb;) and taxama, aor. i; (Ḳ ubi suprà;) and Ait-axama ↓; (Mṣb, and Ṣ and Ḳ, &c. in art. wxm;) He suffered from indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach arising from food which it was too weak to digest; (Mṣb in art. wxm;) he suffered from a disease produced by unsuitable [or unwholesome] food, (Ḳ and TA in art. wxm,) or by fulness of the stomach: (TA in that art.:) followed by mina AlT-aEaAmi and Eani AlT-aEaAmi. (Ṣ and TA in that art.)
3. tAxm, [inf. n. mutaAxamapN,] It (a land or country) bordered upon, or was conterminous with or to, another land or country. (AHeyth, Mgh, Ḳ.)

4. Atxmhu, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wxm,) originally Oawoxamahu; (Ṣ in that art.,) or formed from tuxamapN, in consequence of imagining the t in this word to be radical; (MF;) said of food, It caused him to suffer from tuxamap [or indigestion]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wxm.)
8: see 1.

taxomN The limit, or boundary, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) of any town (Ṣ) or land: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. tuxuwmN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) a poet (Aboo-Keys Ibn-El-Aslat, TA) says,
yaA baniI-a Alt-uxuwmu laA taZolimuwhaA , (Fr, Ṣ,) or, as some relate it, Alt-axuwmu↓: (TA:) accord. to the former reading, Fr says, the meaning is, [O my sons,] the limits, or boundaries, [misplace ye not them], for he does not say taZolimuwhu: but ISK says, I heard AA say, it is taxuwm↓, and the pl. is tuxumN; like SabuwrN and SuburN: (Ṣ:) both IAạr and ISk say that the sing and pl. are like rasuwlN and rusulN: (Mṣb:) but the latter mentions also tuxuwmN, with damm, as a pl. form, having no sing.: (TA:) or taxuwmN↓ signifies a sign, or mark [of a boundary or of a way]: and limits, or boundaries: and is sometimes with [to the t]: (Mgh:) Lth says that txwm [written without any vowel-sign] signifies a division, or place of division, between two districts and two towns or villages; and the limit, or boundary, of the land of any district and town or village is its txwm: and AHeyth says that this word signifies limits, or boundaries: (TA:) or tuxuwmN, with damm, signifies a sign, or mark, and a limit, or boundary, that is a division between two lands; and is of the fem. gender: and the pl. is tuxuwmN also, and tuxumN: (Ḳ:) this app. means that these are pls. of tuxuwmN; but the former is a word that is used as a sing. and as a pl.; and the latter is pl. of taxuwmN, like as SuburN is of SabuwrN, and gufurN of gafuwrN: (TA:) or (as ISk says, TA) the sing. is tuxomN↓ and taxomN (Ḳ) and taxuwmapN↓: (AḤn, Ṣ,* Ḳ:) accord. to AʼObeyd, the Arabic linguists say taxuwmN↓, like SabuwrN, making it fem. and sing.; but the people of Syria say tuxuwmN, with damm to the t, making it pl., and the sing. is taxomN: accord. to IB, one says taxuwmN↓ and tuxuwmN, and zabuwrN and zubuwrN, and EacuwbN and EucuwbN; and no fourth instance of the kind is known; [but see EacuwbN;] and the Basrees pronounce it with damm [to the t], and the Koofees with fet-ḥ. (TA.) It is said in a trad., maloEuwnN mano gay-ara tuxuwma AlOaroDi, meaning, accord. to AʼObeyd, [Cursed is he who alters] the limits, or boundaries, of land; and the signs, or marks, of the way: or, as some say, the limits, or boundaries, of the sacred territory. (TA.) And AjEl hm-k txwmFA, [or rather AijoEalo liham-ika taxuwmFA↓,] means ‡ [Set thou to thy purpose] a limit, to which go thou, and pass not beyond it. (TA.) And huwa Tay-ibu Alt-uxuwmi † He is good in respect of ancestry, or origin: (JK:) or in respect of natural dispositions; or, as some relate the saying, Alt-axuwmi↓. (TA.) tuxuwmN also signifies † A state, or condition, that one desires [app. as the limit of his wish]. (IAạr, Sh, Ḳ.)
tuxomN: see taxomN.

tuxamapN, (Mṣb in the present art., and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wxm,) originally wuxomapN, (Mṣb, and Ṣ in art. wxm,) and tuxomapN, (Mṣb, and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wxm,) the latter vulgar, (Ṣ in art. wxm,) but occurring in poetry, (Ṣ and Ḳ in that art.,) Indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach arising from food which it is too weak to digest; (Mṣb in art. wxm;) a disease produced by unsuitable [or unwholesome] food, (Ḳ and TA in that art.,) or by fulness of the stomach: (TA ibid.:) pl. tuxamaAtN (Ṣ and Ḳ ibid.) and tuxamN. (Mṣb, and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wxm.)
taxuwmN: see taxomN, in seven places.
tuxuwmN pl. of taxomN, which see throughout: and also used as a sing.
taxuwmapN: see taxomN.
TaEaAmN matoxamapN, (JK, and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wxm,) originally mawoxabapN, (Ṣ in art. wxm,) Food that causes one to suffer from tuxamap [or indigestion]. (JK, and Ḳ in art. wxm.)
mutaAximN Conterminous to a land (liOaroDK). (Mgh.) You say also, huwa mutaAximiI He is my neighbour, his house, or tent, adjoining mine. (TA in art. jmd.)

hom.sense: 1. tar-a, (T, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yatoriru} and _u {yatoruru}, (M, Ḳ,) the latter irregular, (TA,) inf. n. tar-N and turuwrN, (M, Ḳ,) It (a bone, M, Ḳ, or anything, M,) became severed, separated, or cut off, (T, M, Ḳ,) by a blow, or stroke [of a sword, &c.]. (M, A.) And tar-ato yaduhu, inf. n. turuwrN, His arm, or hand, became cut off; (M;) and in like manner, any member: (TA:) or fell off; as also Tar-ato. (Ṣ in art. Tr.)

tar-ati Aln-awaApu, (Ṣ, M, A,)) aor. _i {yatoriru}, (Ṣ, M,) and _u, (Ṣ,) inf. n. turuwrN, (T, M,) The date-stone leaped, (T, M,) or went forth, (Ṣ, A,) from the [mess called] Hayos [in the process of kneading], (T,) or from the stone with which it was to be broken. (Ṣ, A.)
tar-a Eano qawomihi He was, or became, apart, or separated, from his people. (Aṣ, T.)
tar-a Eano baladihi He was, or became, or went, far from his country, or town. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
tar-a, (M,) aor. _i {yatoriru}, (TA,) inf. n. tar-N, (Ḳ,) He (an ostrich) ejected what was in his belly. (M, Ḳ.)
tar-a bisaloHihi, aor. _u {yatoruru} and _i, He ejected his excrement. (AA, T.)
See also 4, in two places.

tar-a, (T, M, Ḳ,) sec. pers. tarirota, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yatoraru}, (T, M,) and [sec. pers. tararota, aor.] _i, (M,) [and app. sec. pers. tarurota, aor. _u {yatoruru},] inf. n. [of tarirota or tararota] tar-N and [of tararota] turuwrN (M, Ḳ) and [of tarurota] taraArapN, [which last is the most common,] (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He was, or became, plump: (T in explanation of the first verb:) or his body became plump, and his bones full of moisture: (Lth, T, M, Ḳ:) or he became fat, soft, thin-skinned, and plump. (Ṣ.)
And tar-a, aor. _i {yatoriru}, He was, or became, relaxed, or flaccid, from impatience or some other cause. (T. [See taAr-u.])

entry.sense: 4. Atr-; (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) and tar-a↓, (IDrd, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tar-N; (IDrd, M;) or the former only; (M;) He cut off (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) a man's arm, or hand, by a blow, or stroke, (T, Ṣ, M, A,) of a sword; (T, Ṣ, A;) made it to fall off: (Ṣ:) and in like manner, any member: (M:) as also ATr- and ATn-. (T.)
And the former, (Ṣ, A, TA,) or ↓the latter, (M, as in the TT,) He (a boy) made the piece of wood called qulap to fly away [by striking it] with the miqolaMC. (T, Ṣ,* M,* A,* TA.)
Atr-hu qawomuhu His people separated him from themselves. (Aṣ, T.)
Atr-hu AlqaDaMCu Fate drove him far away from his country, or town. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

R. Q. 1. tarotarahu, inf. n. tarotarapN, He moved, put in motion, put into a state of commotion, agitated, or shook, him, or it: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) he shook him vehemently: (M:) he seized his (a man's) arms, or hands, and shook him: (Lth, T:) he shook him (a drunken man) violently, and ordered him to breath in his face, that he might know what he had drunk; (AA, T, Ḳ;) as also talotalahu, and mazomazahu: (TA:) or tarotarapN and talotalapN and mazomazapN all signify the act of shaking, agitating, or putting in motion, vehemently. (Mgh.)
R. Q. 2. tatarotara He became moved, put in motion, put into a state of commotion, agitated, or shaken. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: tar-N: see taAr-N:
and tur-N.

tur-N The string, or line, which is extended upon, or against, a building, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M,) and according to which one builds, called in Arabic the UimaAm; (Aṣ, M;) the string, or line, by which a building is proportioned: (Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ:) a Persian word, (T, M,) arabicized; (M;) not Arabic: (IAạr:) it is called in Arabic the miTomar. (Aṣ, T.) A man, when angry, says to another, laOuqiyman-aka EalaI Altur-i ‡ [I will assuredly make thee to conform to the rule of right behaviour]. (Lth, T, Ṣ, A.)

I. q. OaSolN: (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) so in the saying, laOaDoTar-an-aka UilaI tur-ika waquHaAHika [I will assuredly impel thee, or drive thee, against thy will, to the utmost point to which thou canst go, or be brought or reduced: or constrain thee to do thine utmost]: (IAạr, T, and L in art. qH: see quHaAHN:) [accord. to ISd,] laOaDoTar-an-aka UilaI tur-ika means UilaI majohuwdika [i. e. I will assuredly make thee to have recourse to thine utmost effort, or endeavour]. (M. [In the Ḳ, the signification of Almajohuwdu is erroneously assigned to Alt-ar-u↓. See also the saying laOulojiYan-aka UilaI qur-i qaraArika explained voce qaraArN.]) tur-aI An arm, or a hand, cut off. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: taraAtiru [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Great, or formidable, or terrible, things or events or affairs: (Ṣ:) distresses, afflictions, or calamities; (M, A, Ḳ;) such as are in war. (A.)

hom.sense: taAr-N A man apart, or separate, from his people. (Aṣ, T.)

Plump (Lth, T, Ṣ, A) in body, (Lth, T,) and having the bones full of moisture; (Lth, T, A;) fat, soft, thin-skinned, and plump: (Ṣ, TA:) applied to a youth: fem. with p {taAr-apN}, applied to a girl; (A, TA;) meaning [plump, &c.: or] beautiful and foolish and soft or weak. (T.) You say, gulaAmN taAr-N TaAr-N [A boy that is plump, and with bones full of moisture, whose mustache is growing forth]. (A.) And qaSabapN taAr-apN [A bone of the kind called qSbp full of moisture]. (A.)
Relaxed, or flaccid, by reason of impatience (jazaE T) or hunger (jawoE Ḳ) [or the contrary (see Oatar-a XaIoCK, below,)] or some other cause: (T, Ḳ:) so says Abu-l-ʼAbbás. (T.)
A tall man; as also tar-N↓, which is app. [a contraction of tarirN,] of the measure faEilN. (M.)

entry.sense: Oatar-a XaIoCK A man in the most relaxed state by reason of fullness of the belly: (TA:) or, accord. to Abu-l-ʼAbbás, by reason of fatigue. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. tariba, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yatorabu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tarabN, (M,) It (a thing) became dusted, or dusty; dust lighted upon it: (Ṣ, TA:) it (a place, M,) had much dust, or earth; abounded with dust, or earth. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
He (a man, M) had dust, or earth, in his hand. (M, Ḳ.)

Also, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He clave to the dust, or earth: (M, Ḳ:) or he clave to the dust, or earth, by reason of poverty; (M;) he became so poor that he clave to the dust, or earth: (AʼObeyd, T:) or he became poor, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) as though he clave to the dust, or earth: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and he suffered loss, and became poor, (M, Ḳ,) so that he clave to the dust, or earth; (M;) inf. n. as above, (M, Ḳ,) and matorabapN, (M,) or matorabN, (Ḳ,) or both of these: (TA:) his wealth became little; (A;) as also Atrb↓, (M, A, Ḳ,) and tr-b↓: (Ḳ:) or Atrb↓ signifies, (T, Ṣ, M,) or signifies also, (A, Ḳ,) and so tariba, (A,) and tr-b↓, (Ḳ,) his wealth became much, or abundant, (T, M, A, Ḳ,) so that it was like the dust, or earth; which is the more known meaning of the verb; (M;) or he became rich; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as though he became possessed of wealth equal in quantity to the dust, or earth: (Ṣ, A:) accord. to Abu-l-ʼAbbás, tatoriybN↓ signifies [the having] much wealth; and also [the having] little wealth. (T.) You say, tariba baEoda maA Oatoraba ↓, meaning He became poor after he had been rich. (A.)

taribato yadaAka, (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, in the M and Ḳ yadaAhu,) a form of imprecation, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) meaning [May thine arms, or thy hands, cleave to the dust, or earth, by reason of poverty; as is implied in the T: or] may thy hands have in them dust, or earth: (Ḥam p. 275:) or mayest thou not obtain, or attain, good: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or mayest thou be unsuccessful, or fail of attaining thy desire, and suffer loss: (A:) occurring in a trad., and as some relate, (AʼObeyd, T,) not meant as an imprecation; (AʼObeyd, T, Mṣb;) being a phrase current with the Arabs, who use it without desiring its fulfilment; (AʼObeyd, T;) but meant to incite, or instigate: (Mṣb:) some say that it means may thy hands become rich; but this is a mistake: (AʼObeyd, T:) and it is said to mean lil-ehi dar-uka [which see in art. dr]: and some say that it is literally an imprecation: but the first assertion is the most worthy of respect, (that it is not meant as an imprecation,) and is corroborated by the saying, in a trad., AinoEimo SabaAHFA taribato yadaAka [Mayest thou have a pleasant morning: may thine arms, or thy hands,, &c.]. (TA.) taribato jabiynuhu [May his forehead (for so jbyn here means, as it does in some other instances,) cleave to the dust, or earth,] was said by Moḥammad in reproving a man, and is said to mean a prayer that the man might be frequent in prostrating himself in prayer. (TA from a trad.) And he said to one of his companions, taribato naHoruka [May the uppermost part of thy breast cleave to the dust, or earth], and the man was [afterwards] slain a martyr: therefore this is to be understood in its obvious sense. (TA.)
See also 4, in four places.
2. tr-b, inf. n. tatoriybN: see 1, in three places:
and see also 4, in four places.

entry.sense: 3. taArabatohaA She became her tirob; (M, Ḳ;) [i. e.] she (a girl) matched her, namely, another girl; she was, or became, her match, fellow, or equal; syn. HaAcatohaA. (A, TA.)
[The inf. n.] mutaArabapN also signifies The associating, or consorting, of OatoraAbN [pl. of tirobN, q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. Atrb: see 1, in three places.
