[or coll. gen. n.] is tan-uwmN: (T: the author of which then adds,) I say, it is a tree which I have seen in the desert: the colour of its leaves inclines to blackness, and it has grains like hemp-seed, or a little larger: I have seen the women of the desert bruise its grains, and express from them a blue oil, in which is a viscosity; and they anoint their hair with it when they comb themselves: AA says, the tn-wm has a grain which is oily and dustcoloured: En-Naḍr says, the tn-wmp is of an ill savour, and the beasts do not like it, or eat much of it: (T:) [it is erroneously said in the Ḳ, voce Tul-aAmN, to be hemp-seed (Hab-u AlX-aAhodaAnij): and] some say that it is the hemp-plant (Xjr AlXhdAnj). (Ḥam p. 135.) The sun, when eclipsed, is said in a trad. to have become black, and like a tn-wmp. (T.) And a poet, who married a woman, and found her to be pretty, but with hoary hair, and who had a youthful wife at his abode, likens the hair of the former to the flower of the OuqoHuwaAn, and black hair to tn-wm; saying
walam-aA raOayotu AlOuqoHuwaAna munaw-irFA
walamo Oara tan-uwmFA tacak-arotu manoziliI
[And when I saw the chamomile flowering, and saw not tennoom, I remembered my abode]. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)

R. Q. 1. tahotahapN, [inf. n. of tahotaha,] i. q. lukonapN [The having an impotence, or an impediment, or a difficulty, or barbarousness, or vitiousness, in speech]: (Ḳ:) or [the having] a distortion in the tongue, (TA,) like what is termed lukonap: (Ṣ, TA:) accord. to Az, tahotahapN and hatohatapN signify the twisting, or distorting, of the tongue in speaking. (TA in art. ht.)

And tahotaha signifies rad-ada fiI AlbaATili, (Ḳ, TA,) or fI AlOabaATiyli, (TA,) [app. meaning He repeated, or used repetitions, in uttering false, or vain, or unprofitable, sayings: but Golius and Freytag render it as meaning he applied himself to vain things.]

taho, (JK,) or tuho tuho, (Ḳ,) An expression imitative of the mutahotih↓, [i. e., of him who has the faulty utterance termed tahotahapN,] (JK, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, Almutatahotihi is put for Almutahotihi,]) consisting in a distortion of the tongue. (JK.)
tuho tuho is also A cry by which one chides the camel, (Ḳ, TA,) and which makes him to run away. (TA.)
And A call to a dog. (Ḳ.)
tiho: see taA in art. tA.
tahaAtihu False, or vain, sayings or actions or affairs; or unprofitable sayings. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mutahotihN: see taho.
taAhuwrN [probably, in its primary acceptation, a dial. var. of tayohuwrN; for the signification here following is said in the TA to be tropical:]
‡ Clouds; or a collection of clouds: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) pl. tawaAhiyru. (JK.)

tayohuwrN, said by Az to be of the measure fayoEuwlN, from Alwahoru; originally wayohuwrN, like as tayoquwrN is [said to be] originally wayoquwrN; but the t is held by ISd [and J and F and others] to be a radical: (TA:) Low, or depressed, sand: (T, TA:) or sand that falls apart, and does not hold together: (A, TA:) or elevated sand: (TA:) or sand having a juruf [or part carried and eaten away by torrents]: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. tayaAhiyru and tayaAhiru. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Low, or depressed, land, or ground. (Ḳ.)
The part between the top and bottom of the side of a valley, and of a mountain: (JK, Ḳ,* TA:) of the dial. of Nejd, and of that of Hudheyl. (TA.)
High waves of the sea or of a great river. (Ḳ.)

Applied to a man, [like tay-aArN, q. v.,] † Vain, or having a fond opinion of himself, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and proud. (Ḳ.) [For caAhiyFA in one copy of the Ṣ, and caAhibFA in another and in the L, in the phrase UicaA kaAna caAhiyFA binafosihi bihi tiyhN, or caAhibFA, I read zaAhiyFA.]

1. tahima, (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yatohamu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tahamN, (Mṣb,) or tahaAmapN, (JK,) It (flesh-meat, JK, Mṣb, Ḳ, and milk, Mṣb, and oil, Ḳ) became altered for the worse, and stank: (JK,* Mṣb, Ḳ:*) it (flesh-meat, TḲ) had a foul odour; it stank. (Ḳ.)
It (the heat) was, or became, vehement, or intense, with stillness of the wind. (Mṣb.)
Also, inf. n. tahamN, He (a camel) was penetrated by the heat: (JK:) or was smitten by the hot wind, and in consequence became lean, or emaciated. (TA.)

And, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. tahamN, (TA,) He (a camel) ate much of the pasture (Aisotakovara mina AlmaroEaI), and it was not wholesome: (JK:) or disapproved the pasture (Aisotanokara AlmaroEaI), and did not find it wholesome, (Ḳ, TA,) and his condition became bad. (TA.)
And, said of a man, His impotence, or inability, became apparent, and he became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (Ḳ.)
3: see 4.

hom.sense:
4. Athm He (a man, Ṣ) went, (Ṣ,) or came, (Ḳ,) to Tihámeh: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) Er-Riyáshee says, I have heard the Arabs of the desert say thus of him who has descended from the mountain-roads of Dhát 'Irk: (TA:) or he alighted, or abode, therein: (Ḳ:) as also taAhama↓, (JK, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, taAh-ama,]) in the latter sense, (JK,)
and tth-m↓; (Ḳ;) or these mean he came to Tihámeh. (TA.)
[Accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss. in the KL, it signifies also, He went into a region of hot air: and this, if correct, may be the primary meaning.]
Athm Albalada He found the country, or town, to be insalubrious, (Ḳ, TA,) and to have a bad, or foul, odour. (TA.)

Athm, inf. n. UitohaAmN; in measure like Oakorama, inf. n. UikoraAmN; (Mṣb;) [originally Awhm; or] formed from tuhamapN, in consequence of imagining the t in this word to be radical; (MF in art. whm;) [like as is said of Oatoxama;] He did a thing that made him an object of suspicion: (JK and Mṣb and TA in the present art.:) or he was an object of suspicion: (Ḳ in art. whm: [in the CK and TḲ, erroneously, At-hm:]) or there was in him that which induced suspicion: you say of a man, when you suspect him, Oatohamota, inf. n. UitohaAmN; like OadowaOota, inf. n. UidowaMCN. (Ṣ in art. whm.)

Athmhu He suspected him; thought evil of him; as also Ait-ahamahu↓ [which is the more common]. (Mṣb in this art.) You say, Athmhu bikacaA, (Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ, both in art. whm,) inf. n. UitohaAmN; (Ḳ in that art.;) or Ait-ahamahu↓ bihi; (Mṣb and Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ, all in that art.;) and Oawohamahu; (Ḳ in that art.;) He suspected him of such a thing; imputed it to him; (Mṣb and Ḳ * and TA, all in that art.;) [and he accused him of such a thing;] i. e., a thing attributed to him. (TA.) And Ait-ahamotuhu↓ fiI qawolihi [I suspected him in respect of his saying;] I doubted of the correctness, or truth, of his saying. (Mṣb in art. whm.)

entry.sense: 5: see 4.
8: see 4, in three places.

tahamN [in the CK, erroneously, tahom] Land descending (OaroDN mutaSaw-ibapN [in the CK, here and afterwards, erroneously, mutaSaw-iyap]) to the sea; as also tahamapN↓; (Ḳ, TA;) mentioned by IḲt, from Ez-Ziyádee, from Aṣ: (TA:) these two words seem to be [originally] inf. ns. from tihaAmapu: (Ḳ:) [and accord. to F,] Alt-ahomapu↓ is a dial. var. of tihaAmapu↓: (Ḳ:) [but J says,] Alt-ahamapu↓ is used in the place of tihaAmapu↓, as though it were [originally] the inf. n. un., accord. to the saying of Aṣ that Alt-ahamu, with fet-ḥ to the medial radical, is an inf. n. from tihaAmapu↓: (Ṣ:) for the tahaAYim↓ [pl. of tihaAmapu, and thus meaning the parts of Tihámeh, or, accord. to the JK, meaning lands descending to the sea,] do descend to the sea: (Ḳ, TA:) so says Aṣ: (TA:) and [hence] the rájiz says, (namely, Sheytán Ibn-Mudlij, TA,)
naZarotu waAlEayonu mubiynapu Alt-ahamo
[I looked, the eye distinguishing Et-Taham], (Ṣ, and Ḥam p. 659,) meaning Et-Tihámeh. (Ḥam ibid.)
[As inf. n. of tahima, q. v.,] Alt-ahamu also signifies Vehemence of heat, and [or with] stillness of the wind. (Ḳ.) And hence Tihámeh is said to be thus called. (TA.)

hom.sense: tahimN, applied to flesh-me., Altered for the worse; (JK;) having a foul odour; stinking. (JK,* Ḳ.)
OaroDN tahimapN A land vehemently, or intensely, hot. (Er-Riyáshee, TA.)
Sleeping; (JK;) i. q. tahinN. (TA in art. lEv.)

entry.sense: Alt-ahomapu: see tahamN.

It, (Ḳ,) or Alt-ahamapu↓, (JK,) signifies also Albalodapu [app. as meaning Mekkeh, like tihaAmapu↓; as though the city of cities]: (JK, Ḳ:) so in the phrase Oaholu Alt-ahamapi↓ [which may mean The people of Mekkeh; and also, of Tihá- meh, in the more extended sense of the latter appellation]. (JK.)
tuhomapN: see tuhamapN.
fiyhi tahamapN In it is a foul odour; a stink. (Ḳ.)
See also tahamN.
Alt-ahamapu: see tahamN, and Alt-ahomapu; the latter in two places.

tuhamapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c., in art. whm, and Mṣb in that art. and in the present also,) of which tuhomapN↓ is a dial. var. mentioned by El-Fárábee (Mṣb, and TA in art. whm) and by several other authors, or, accord. to Ibn-Kemál, the latter is an inf. n. and the former is a simple subst., but Esh-Shiháb doubts of this; (TA;) originally wahamapN, (Ṣ, ISd, Mṣb, &c.,) like as tuxamapN is originally wuxamapN; (ISd, TA;) a subst. from Ait-ahamahu; (Ṣ, Mṣb, both in art. whm;) Doubt: and [more commonly] suspicion, or evil opinion; or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion: syn. Xak-N: and riybapN: (Mṣb in the present art.:) or i. q. Zan-N [which is a preponderating wavering between the two extremes of indecisive belief; and often means suspicion]: (ISd and TA in art. whm:) or a thing for which one is suspected: (Ḳ in that art.: [and this is often meant by riybapN, one of the syns. mentioned above:]) the pl. of tuhomapN is tuhamN, mentioned by Sb, who argues that it is a pl. [and not a coll. gen. n.] from their saying hiIa Alt-uhamu [They are suspicions,, &c.], and not saying huwa Alt-uhamu like as they say huwa Alr-uTabu. (TA in art. whm.)
tahaAmK: see tihaAmiI-N.

tahiymN Suspected; thought evil of; (JK in this art., and Mṣb in this and in art. whm;) [as also mut-ahamN↓ and mutohamN↓:] or being an object of suspicion; as also mutohimN↓. (Ḳ in art. whm. [In the CK, the latter is erroneously written mut-ahimN.])

tihaAmapu a name of Mekkeh: (JK, Ḳ:) and [more commonly] a certain land, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) commencing from Dhát 'Irk, (Mṣb, TA,) towards Nejd, (Mṣb,) and extending to Mekkeh and beyond it to the distance of two day's journeys (Mṣb, TA) and more, then uniting with the Ghowr, and extending to the sea: some say that it adjoins the land of El-Yemen; and that Mekkeh is of tihaAmapu Alyamani: (Mṣb:) [F says that] J has erred in terming it a balad: (Ḳ:) [but by bld, J may mean both a city and a country or province:] some say that its name is from tahima in the first of the senses assigned to this verb above, because it is low in relation to Nejd, so that its odour is bad; and some, that it is from the same verb in the sense explained in the second sentence, because of its vehement heat: (Mṣb:) [it seems to have tahaAYimu for a pl.:] see tahamN, in four places; and Alt-ahomapu.

tihaAmiI-N Of, or belonging to, Tihámeh; as also tahaAmK↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, tahAmN,]) with fet-ḥ, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) irregularly formed; (M, Mṣb;) fem. tahaAmiyapN; like rabaAEK and rabaAEiyapN: (T, Mṣb:) when it is pronounced with fet-ḥ to the t, it is without teshdeed [to the I when you say Alt-ahaAmiI and tahaAmiyapN]; as in the instances of rajulN yamaAnK and XaMmK, except that the A in tahaAmK is of the original word, and that in yamaAnK and XaMmK is a substitute for the two I of the [regular] rel. n., (Ṣ,) or rather, for one of those two I: (Aboo-Zekereeyà, TA:) and you say qawomN tahaAmuwna [A people, or company of men, of Tihámeh], like yamaAnuwna: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and accord. to Sb, some say tahaAmiI-N and yamaAniI-N and XaMmiI-N, with fet-ḥ, and with teshdeed [to the I]. (Ṣ.)
mutohamN: see tahiymN.

hom.sense: mutohimN [Going, or coming, to Tihámeh: or alighting, or abiding, therein: and] alighting, or abiding, in Mekkeh. (TA.)
waAdK mutohimN A valley of which the water pours to Tihámeh. (TA.)
See also tahiymN.

entry.sense: mitohaAmN Often coming to Tihámeh: (Ṣ Ḳ:) pl. mataAhiymu (Ṣ, TA) and mataAhimu, (TA,) applied to men (Ṣ, TA) and to camels. (TA.)
mut-ahamN: see tahiymN.

hom.sense: 4. AtwI, said of a man, signifies jaMCa taw-FA, i. e. He came alone; by himself: opposed to OazowaI meaning “he came with another.” (T.)
See also art. twI.

taw-N [app. from the Persian tuwo, meaning “a fold,” or “a single fold,”,] One, and no more; single; sole. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) You say, kaAna taw-FA faSaAra zaw-FA He, or it, was one only, and became a pair. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., AlT-awaAfu taw-N waAlAisotijomaAru taw-N, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e., The circuiting [of the Kaabeh] is one action, and the casting of the pebbles [in the valley of Minè] is one action. (TA.) You say also, jaMCa taw-NA, meaning He came alone; by himself: (T, Ṣ, M:) or he came by a direct course, nothing making him to deviate, and not stopping anywhere in the road; for if he stop anywhere in the road, he is not said to be tw-. (AZ, AʼObeyd, M, Ḳ.) And Eaqadotuhu bitaw-K waAHidK I tied it with a single knot; by turning the cord, or the like, once: so says AZ; and he cites the following ex.:
jaAriyapN layosato mina AlwaHoXan-i
laA taEoqidu AlmanoTaqa biAlmuXotan-i
Uil-aA bitaw-K waAHidK Oawo tan-i
i. e., [A girl that is not of the wild, or shy, sort: she does not tie the zone with the fist, but with a single knot, or] half a knot:
the n in tan- [and in waHoXan- and muXotan-] is redundant: tan- being originally ta, which is a contraction [or rather the half, both as to the letter and the meaning,] of taw-. (T.)
A rope that is twisted of a single strand: pl. OatowaMCN. (T, M, Ḳ.)

[It is said that] it signifies also A thousand horses, or horsemen. (AZ, T, Ḳ.) [But this requires consideration: for] one says, waj-aha fulaAnN mino xayolihi biOalofK taw-K, (AZ, T, Ṣ,) meaning [Such a one sent a troop of his horses] with a thousand men; i. e., with one thousand: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as some say, with one complete thousand. (TA.)
Also One who is unoccupied by the business of the present world and of the world to come. (AA, T, Ḳ.*)
Also A structure elevated, reared, or erected. (T, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: taw-apN A period, or a short period, (saAEapN, AA, T, Ḳ,) of time. (AA, T.) You say, maDato taw-apN mina All-ayoli, and Aln-ahaAr, A period, or a short period, (sAEp,) of the night passed, and of the day. (TA.) And maA maDaI Uil-aA Hat-aI kaAna kacaA There passed not save a short period (sAEp) to the time that such a thing happened. (IAạr, T.) Hence the saying of the vulgar, taw-apF qaAma [commonly pronounced taw-aho] Just now (Als-aAEapa) he rose, or stood. (TA.)
taMCN The name of the letter t, q. v.; as also taA: pl. [of the former taMCaAtN; and of the latter] OatowaMCN. (TA in bAb AlAlf All-ynp.)

taAYiI-N and taAwiI-N rel. ns. of taMCN and taA the names of the letter t; as also tayawiI-N: (TA ubi suprà:) whence qaSiydapN taAYiy-apN and taAwiy-apN and tayawiy-apN (T, Ḳ, TA, ubi suprà, [the last written in the CK tayowiy-apN,] and the second is also mentioned in the Ṣ) A qSydp of which the rawiI-. is t (TA ibid.)

1. taAba, (T, A,) or tAb UilaI Qll-ehi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. yatuwbu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. tawobapN and tawobN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) both of these signifying the same, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) the p in the former being added to denote the fem. gender, or, as some say, the former is a n. un. like DarobapN, (Mṣb,) or, as Akh says, tawobN is pl. [or a quasi-pl. n.] of tawobapN, like as EawomN is of EawomapN, (Ṣ,) or like as lawozN is of lawozapN, and this is the opinion of Mbr, (M,) and taAbapN, (M, Ḳ,) which is for tawobapN, (M,) and mataAbN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and tatowibapN, (Ṣ,* M,* Ḳ,) of the measure tafoEilapN, (Ṣ, M,) an anomalous form, (TA,) syn. with tawobapN, mentioned in the Book of Sb; (Ṣ;) [He repented; or repented toward God; as will be shown by what follows:] originally, he returned unto God, (T, TA,) mino kacaA and Eano kacaA [from such a thing]: (TA:) or he returned, [or returned unto God,] (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) from sin, (Ṣ,) or from his sin, (A,) or from disobedience (M, Ḳ) to obedience: (M:) or taAba mino canobihi signifies he desisted from his sin: (Mṣb:) tawobapN signifies the repenting of sin; i. e. the grieving for it, or regretting it, with the confession of having no excuse for the commission thereof. (Kull.) It is said in a trad., Aln-adamu tawobapN [Repentance is] a returning from sin. (Ṣ.) The time of El-Islám is termed zamanu Alt-awobapi as being The time of returning from [or repenting of] the belief in a plurality of gods. (A.) A poet says,
tubotu Uilayoka fataqab-alo taAbatiI
waSumotu rab-iI fatafab-alo SaAmatiI
[I have repented toward Thee, and accept Thou my repentance; and I have fasted, O my Lord, and accept Thou my fast]; meaning tawobatiI and SawomatiI. (M.)

taAba Qll-ehu Ealayohi God returned to forgiveness towards him; became again forgiving to him: (T:) or disposed, or adapted, him to repentance, or returning from sin or disobedience: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or reverted from severity to mildness towards him: or returned to him with his favour, or grace, and his acceptance, or approbation; became again propitious to him: (A, Ḳ:) all these meanings are correct: (TA:) or God forgave him, and saved him from acts of disobedience: (Mṣb:) or accepted his repentance: (Jel in ii. 35, &c.:) or returned towards him with mercy, and acceptance of repentance. (Bḍ ibid.)

10. AsttAbhu He proposed to him that he should return [to obedience unto God], (T, A,) and repent of that which he had committed: (T:) he asked him to return from sin, or disobedience: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he asked him to desist from his sin. (Mṣb.)

taAbuwtN, originally tawabuwtN, the t not being the characteristic of the fem. gender, (Z, MF, TA,) of the measure faEaluwtN, and meaning A chest, or box, from Alt-awobu, because what is taken out from it continually returns to it: (AAF, IJ, Z, MF, TA:) or originally taAbuwapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ; [in the CK taOobuwapN;]) the w being made quiescent, and the p changed into t: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [in Chald. תֵּיבוּתָא: in Hebr. תֵּבָה:] it signifies also the ribs, with what they contain, as the heart and the liver, &c.; as being likened to a chest, or box; (IAth, TA in art. tbt;) the chest, breast, or bosom: (A in that art.:) or [primarily] the ribs, with what they contain, as the heart, &c.: and [hence] applied to a chest, or box: (Towsheeh, MF, TA:) also written tabuwtN. (Ḳ in art. tbt.) [It is generally applied in the present day to a bier: a coffin: and an oblong case that is placed over a grave: the pl. is tawaAbiytu.] El-Kásim Ibn-Maan says that it is the only word in the Ḳur-án in respect of which the dialects of Kureysh and the Ansár differ; the former pronouncing it taAbuwtN; (Ṣ;) and the latter, taAbuwhN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) But IB denies that its last letter is originally p, the fem. termination; asserting the final t to be a radical letter, the measure of the word to be faAEuwlN, and its proper place in art. tbt: he says that the final t is changed in a case of pause, but not generally, into h, as is that of AlfuraAt [the Euphrates], in which the t is not the fem. termination. (L, TA.) You say, maA OawodaEotu taAbuwtiI XayoYFA faqadotuhu, meaning I have not deposited in my bosom anything of knowledge, or science, that I have lost. (A in art. tbt.)
taw-aAbN, applied to a man, [One who repents much or often;] returning from disobedience to obedience [to God] (M, Ḳ, TA) much or often. (TA.)

And applied to God, One who returns [much or often] to forgiveness towards his servant who returns unto Him: (T:) or who [often] disposes, or adapts, to repentance, or returning from sin or disobedience; or reverts from severity to mildness; or returns with his favour or grace,, &c.: (A, Ḳ: [see 1, last sentence:]) or who forgives much, and save from acts of disobedience. (Mṣb.)
taAYibN [Repenting of sin: (see 1:) originally,] returning from disobedience (M, Ḳ) to obedience to God. (M.)

tuwtN (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tuwvN; (Mgh, and L and Ḳ in art. twv, q. v.;) the latter sometimes used; (Mṣb;) or this is not allowable; (ISk, T, Ṣ, Mṣb;) for the word, which is app. Persian, is pronounced by the Arabs with t for the final as well as for the initial letter; (T, Mṣb;) [The mulberry; and especially the white mulberry;] i. q. firoSaAdN: (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the people of El-Basrah, (Mṣb,) or some of the people of El-Basrah, (Mgh,) twt is the name of the fruit, and frSAd is that of the tree; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and this is what is commonly held: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to IDrd and others, twt is an arabicized word, and frSAd is the Arabic name: (TA:) [twt is a coll. gen. n.:] the n. un. is with p {tuwtapN}. (M.) [Golius says, in his Lex., on the authority of Zeyn El-'Attár, that there are three kinds: “twt Hlw,” i. e. HulowN, “the sweet and white mulberry, peculiarly called frSAd; and twt HAmD,” i. e. HaAmiDN, ““the sour and black mulberry; and twt wHXI,” i. e. waHoXiI-N, “and twt AlElyq,” i. e. AlEul-ayoqN, “the wild mulberry, i. e., with red fruit.” In Egypt, twt is applied to the sweet mulberry, white and black, and especially to the former, as also twt baladiI-; and twt XaAmiI- to the latter. In the present day, twt AlEul-ayoq is applied to the raspberry; as also twt XawokiI-: and twt waHoXiI-, I believe, to the blackberry. twt OaroDiI- and twt UiforanojiI- are applied to the strawberry.]

tuwtiyaMCN, [of the masc. gender, as is shown by the phrase twtyAC maEodaniI-N, and therefore perfectly decl.,] an arabicized word, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [Tutia, or tutty; an impure protoxide of zinc;] a certain stone [or mineral], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known, (M, Ḳ,) employed as a collyrium. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
[It is also applied in the present day to several kinds of vitriol; the sulphates of zinc and of copper and of iron. De Sacy says, on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, that there are two species thereof; one which is found in mines; the other, in the furnaces in which copper is melted, like cadmia; and this latter species is what the Greeks call pompholyx: of the fossil tutia there are three varieties; one is white; another, greenish; the third, yellow, with a strong tinge of red: the white is the finest variety; the green, the coarsest. (Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., iii. 453; where see more.) Golius, on this word, in his Lex., says, “Optima est quæ vel naturalis, sc. Indica, cærulea, et pellucida; vel artificialis, sc. Carmanica, alba cum partis viridioris strictura. Zein.” i. e. Zeyn El-'Attár. “Ex plumbi præstantissimi, quod dicitur qlEI, fuligine concrescere præstantissimum genus, commune vero ex fuligine æris, tradit Jacutus ex Abulfed.”.]
tuwtiyaMCN: see the art. next preceding.

tuwvN i. q. qiroSaAdN; a dial. var. of tuwtN, [q. v.,] mentioned by IF, (L, Ḳ,) and by AḤn, who cites a verse in which it occurs, and says that he had not heard any one pronounce it with t, but only with v, though twv is Persian and twt is Arabic; (IB, TA;) but it is disallowed by El-Ḥareeree and others: (TA:) in the Expos. of the work entitled Adab el-Kátib, it is said that twt is an arabicized word, originally twv and twc: (Mz, MF:) the n. un. is with p {tuwvapN}. (L, Ḳ.)
2. tw-jhu He crowned him; invested him with the crown. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,* Ḳ.)
He made him a prince, lord, or chief. (Mṣb,* TA.)
† He turbaned him; invested him with the turban. (TA.)

5. ttw-j He was, or became, crowned, or invested with the crown. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) [For the verb taAja, in this or a similar sense, mentioned in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag, in the former as from the Ḳ, I find no authority: on the contrary, it is said in the TA that no verb answering to taAYijN has been heard.]
He was made, or became, a prince, lord, or chief. (TA.)
† He was, or became, turbaned, or invested with the turban. (TA.)

taAjN A crown; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. a thing that is made for kings, of gold and jewels; (TA;) peculiar to the Eajam [or Persians and other foreigners]: (Mṣb:) [a Persian word:] pl. [of mult.] tiyjaAnN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OatowaAjN. (TA.)

† A turban; as being likened to a crown. (TA.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) AlEamaAYimu tiyjaAnu AlEarabi [Turbans are the crowns of the Arabs]; (Ṣ, TA;) i. e. turbans are to the Arabs as crowns to the kings; for the Arabs in the deserts are [or were] mostly bare-headed or wearing qalaAnis [pl. of qalanosuwapN, q. v.]; turbans among them being few. (TA.)
Also Silver. (TA.) [See what next follows.]
taAjapN An ingot of purified silver: originally taAzaho, a Persian word, applied to a dirhem recently coined. (TA.)
taAYijN Having a taAj [i. e. crown, or † turban]; an epithet applied to an UimaAm: (Ḳ:) it is a possessive epithet, like daAriEN, for we have not heard any verb answering to it. (TA.)
mutaw-ajN Crowned; applied to a king: (A, TA:) † made a prince, lord, or chief: † turbaned. (TA.)

mataAwiju [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] occurring in the saying of Jendel Er-Rá'ee,
wahun-a yaEomiyna mina AlmalaAmiji
biqaridK muxoranoTimi AlmataAwiji
signifies [properly The parts of the head] where one is crowned (Hayovu yutataw-aju) with the turban: (Ḳ,* TA:) [but it is evidently here used in a tropical manner; the poet is speaking of she-camels:] the mlAmj are the mouths; [or the parts around the mouths;] and the qarid, a word like katif, is the accumulated foam which the camel casts forth from his mouth. (TA.) [It seems that the poet means, And they cast forth, from the parts around the mouth, accumulated foam, elongated in the extremities: muxoranoTim being app. syn. with muxaroTam, as meaning “elongated like a xuroTuwm,” or “snout.”]
1. taAHa, aor. yatuwHu, inf. n. tawoHN: see taAHa in art. tyH.

hom.sense: 1. taAra, aor. yatuwru, (TA in art. tyr,) inf. n. taworN, (Ḳ,) It (water, TA) ran, or flowed: (Ḳ, TA:) but this verb is obsolete. (TA in art. tyr.)
tiyra Alr-ajulu [app. for vuYira] Blood-revenge was had of the man. (M. [See also taArapN.])

entry.sense: 3. tAwrhu He returned to him, or it, time after time; syn. EaAwadahu. (A. [See also 4.])
4. AtArhu He repeated it, or did it again, time after time. (Ṣ in art. tyr, M, Ḳ.)

He continued to look at him, or it, time after time. (TA.) And Oatarotu Uilayohi Aln-aZara, (T, Ḳ *) and Alr-amoIa, inf. n. UitaArapN, (T,) i. q. OatoOarotuhu, (Ḳ,) i. e. I looked at him sharply, or intently: (TA:) [or time after time:] and I cast, or shot, at him time after time. (T.)

fulaAnN yutaAru EalaI Oano yuWoxaca is said by AA to mean Such a one is encompassed, or gone round, (yudaAru,) in order that he may be taken: and he cites, from a poem of ' Ámir Ibn-Ketheer El-Moháribee,
laqado gaDibuwA EalaI-a waOaXoqacuwniI
faSirotu kaOan-aniI faraON yutaAru
[as though meaning They have been angry with me, and driven me away, and I have become as though I were a wild ass encompassed in order to be taken]: or, accord. as some relate it, mutaAru↓: (Ṣ:) [and it is said that] this signifies cast at, or shot at, time after time. (T, L. [See also art. tOr.])
taArN: see taArapN.

hom.sense: taworN A messenger (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) between people, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or that goes about between lovers: (A:) accord. to IDrd, (Ṣ,) a genuine Arabic word: (Ṣ, M:) pl. OatowaArN. (Mṣb.) And taworapN A girl who is sent on messages between lovers. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

A vessel, (Ṣ,) a certain wellknown vessel, (T, Mṣb,) a small vessel, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) from which one drinks: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) a vessel of brass, or of stone, like the Uij-aAnap: (TA:) sometimes also used for the ablution termed wuDuwoC: (A, Mgh, TA:) so called from the same word as signifying the act of “running” or “flowing” [of water], (TA,) because it is mutually borrowed and returned; or from the same word as signifying “a messenger:” (A, TA:) of the masc. gender: (T, A, Ḳ:) [or fem., for Z says,] I passed, at the Gate of El-'Omrah, [of the Temple of Mekkeh,] by a woman who was saying to her female neighbour, OaEiyriyniI tuwayorataki [Lend thou to me thy little tawor: for had she considered twr as masc., she would have said tuwayoraki]. (A.)
taworN nuHaAsN A cooking-pot of copper. (Mgh.)
taworu AlmaMCi i. q. TuHolubN, i. e. A green substance that overspreads stagnant water. (Mṣb.)

taArapN, originally with C, which is suppressed on account of frequent usage, (IAạr, Mṣb,) and sometimes pronounced with C; (Mṣb;) or its A is [originally] w [and therefore it is mentioned in most of the lexicons in the present art.]; (Lth, T;) [or I, for it is mentioned in the Ṣ in art. tyr;] A time; one time; [in the sense of the French fois;] syn. mar-apN: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and a time, whether long or short; syn. HiynN: (M, Ḳ:) sometimes [pronounced taArN↓,] without p: (Ṣ:) pl. taAraAtN (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tiyarN; (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) the latter a contraction of tiyaArN; like as they said qaAmaAtN and qiyamN, because of the unsound letter. (Ṣ. [See also art. tOr.]) You say, faEala celika taArapF baEoda taArapF He did that time after time. (Ṣ.) And hecihi Xar-N taAraAtika This is the worst of thy times. (A.)

yaA taAraAti fulaAnK [app. meaning O the blood-revenge of such a one!] (M, Ḳ) is mentioned by Lḥ, (M,) or AA, (TA,) but not explained by him: and he cites the saying of Hassán,
latasomaEan-a waXiykFA fiI diyaArihimu
Aall-ehu Oakobaru yaA taAraAti EuvomaAna [which probably means Thou wilt assuredly hear speedily, in their abodes, “God is most great! O the blood-revenge of 'Othmán!” for ISd says,] in my opinion, (M,) tArAt is formed by transposition from witorN signifying blood [or rather bloodrevenge], (M, Ḳ,*) though not agreeing with it in measure: (M:) and wXykA here means sariyEFA: so says IB. (TA in art. wXk.) [See also vaOorN.]

entry.sense: taAYirN Applying himself constantly, or perseveringly, to work, after remitting, or remissness. (Ḳ.)
tay-aArN: see art. tyr.
mutaArN: see 4.

1. taAqa Uilayohi, (Ḳ,) aor. yatuwqu, (TA,) inf. n. tawoqN and tuWuwqN and tiyaAqapN and tawaqaAnN, He yearned towards, longed for, or desired, him or it; (Ḳ, TA;) his soul yearned towards, longed for, or desired, him or it. (TA.) And taAqato nafosiI UilaI AlX-aIoCi, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, but in the latter two nafosuhu,) inf. n. tawoqN (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb) and tuWuwqN (JK, Mṣb) and tawaqaAnN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) My soul yearned towards, longed for, or desired, the thing; (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) and hastened to it: (Mṣb:) and so tAqt AlX-aIoCa. (TA.)

taAqa UilaI AlX-aIoCi also signifies ‡ He desired, or purposed, to do the thing: and he was brisk, or prompt, to do it: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) so in the Moḥeeṭ. (TA.) You say, tAq UilaI AlgaAyapi ‡ He hastened, with briskness, or promptness, to the goal. (TA.) And tuqo UilaI-a yaA fulaAnu ‡ Hasten thou to me, O such a one. (TA.)
taAqa AlqidoHu The gaming-arrow came forth on the occasion of the shuffling in the game of Almayosir: (JK,* Ḳ, TA:) so says Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)
taAqati Ald-umuwEu ‡ The tears issued from their channels. (JK, Ḳ, TA.)

taAqa binafosihi, inf. n. tawaqaAnN (JK, Ḳ) and tawoqN, (Ḳ, TA,) or tawaqN, (CK,) i. q. jaAda binafosihi [He gave up his spirit: or he was near to die]: (JK, Ḳ:) said of a man: (JK:) AA says that Alt-awoqu signifies the being in the very agony of death; like Als-awoqu. (TA.)
taAqa is also also syn. with OaXofaqa, (JK, Ḳ,) accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.) You say, taAqa minohu, meaning He was cautious, or in fear, of him or it. (TḲ.)

5. ttw-q UilaI AlX-aIoCi He was, or became, excited by a yearning towards, a longing for, or a desire for, the thing; or he affected and showed a yearning towards it, a longing for it, or a desire for it; syn. taXaw-aqa. (TA.)
tawaqapN Persons convalescent; or in a state of recovery from disease, but not yet completely restored to health and strength: (IAạr, Ḳ:) app. pl. of taAYiqN↓. (TA.)

taw-aAqN i. q. Xaw-aAqN [app. Yearning, longing, or desiring, much, or vehemently; or very desirous: but some regard it as a simple epithet, syn. with taAYiqN↓; for it is said that] nafosN taw-aAqapN signifies the same as taAYiqapN↓ [A yearning, longing, desiring, or desirous, soul]. (JK, Mṣb.) It is said in a prov., (TA,)
AlmaroCu taw-aAqN UilaI maA lamo yanalo
[Man is desirous, or very desious, of that which he has not attained]. (Ṣ, TA.)
One whose soul yearns towards, longs for, or desires, every low, or base, action. (TA.)
taAYiqN and its fem. with p {taAYiqapN}: see taw-aAqN; and see tawaqapN.
tay-iqaAnN, originally tayowiqaAnN, A man who leaps, springs, or bounds, vehemently. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
mutaw-aqN Yearned towards, longed for, desired, or desired eagerly. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
tawolabN: see art. tlb.
tuwmN: see tuwmapN, below, in two places.
tawamN: see tawoCamN, in art. tOm.

tuwmapN sing. of tuwamN [in the CK, erroneously, tuWamN] and [n. un.] of tuwmN↓; (M, Ḳ;) One of the things called tuwmu; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) i. e. a quroT [as meaning a silver bead fashioned like a pearl]: (Lth, T:) or a quroT [as meaning an earring] in which is a large Hab-ap [or bead]: (M, Ḳ:) or a thing, (T,) or Hab-ap [i. e. bead], (Ṣ, Mṣb,) made of silver, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) like a pearl, (T, Ṣ,) or like a large pearl, (Ṣ,) of a round form, which a girl puts in her ear. (T.)
And hence, as being likened to this, (T,) † A large pearl: (AA, T:) or a pearl. (M, Ḳ.) And Oum-u tuwmapa The pearl-shell: (Ḳ, TA:) a proper name, and therefore imperfectly decl. (TA.)

And ‡ An ostrich's egg: (M, Ḳ, TA:) pl. as above: (M:) ostriches' eggs are called tuwmN↓ (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ) as being likened to pearls, which are thus called: (T:) they are so called by Dhu-r-Rummeh, where he says,
waHat-aI OataI yawomN yakaAdN mina All-aZaI
bihi Alt-uwmu fiI OufHuwSihi yataSay-aHu
[And until there came a day in which, by reason of the flaming heat, the ostriches' eggs, in the place where they were deposited in the sand, almost dried up.] (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M.)
Alt-uwmataAni is an appellation applied to two kaseedehs of Jereer, in praise of' Abd-El-'Azeez Ibn-Marwán. (T.)
mutaw-amN Having a qilaAdap [or necklace] put upon his neck; syn. muqal-adN. (Ḳ. [In the CK, erroneously, muqal-id.])

1. taAha, aor. yatuwhu, inf. n. tawoCN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and tuwhN, (AZ, Ḳ,) is syn. with taAha having for its aor. yatiyhu; (Mṣb, and TA in the present art. and in art. tyh;) [and with TaAHa, aor. yaTuwHu and yaTiyHu;] signifying He deviated from, or lost, or missed, the right way; he lost his way; (Mṣb, TA;) in the desert: (Mṣb:) or he was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (TA in the present art.:) or he went away (Ḳ, TA) in the land, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (TA in art. tyh:) or, as some say, (TA,) his mind, or intellect, was, or became, disordered, confused, or unsound: (Ḳ, TA:) and he perished: (Ḳ TA:) accord. to ISd, the I in yatiyhu is shown to be originally w by their saying, maA Oatowahahu, as syn. with maA Oatoyahahu. (TA.) AZ says, A man of the Benoo-Kiláb said to me, OaloqayotaniI fiI Alt-uwhi, with damm, meaning [Thou hast thrown me into] destruction. (TA.)
Also, [like taAha aor. yatiyhu, q. v.,] He magnified himself; or behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently. (Ḳ.)

2. tw-hhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tatowiyhN, (TA,) i. q. tay-ahahu, [and Taw-aHahu and Tay-aHahu,] i. e. He made him to deviate from, or lose, or miss, the right way; made him to lose his way: (Mṣb:) [or he made him to be, or become, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course:, &c.: see 1; and see tay-ahahu, in art. tyh:] or he destroyed him. (Ḳ.)

4. maA Oatowahahu i. q. maA Oatayohahu [How extraordinary is he in deviating from, or losing, or missing, the right way! in losing his way! or in confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see his right course!, &c.: see 1]: (Ḳ in the present art., and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. tyh:) as also maA OaTowaHahu (TA in art. tyh) and maA OaToyaHahu. (Ṣ and TA in that art.)
10. AsttAhhu [He, or it, invited him to deviate from, or lose, or miss, the right way; to lose his way]; from taAha, aor. [yatuwhu and] yatiyhu, signifying Dal-a. (Ḥam p. 685.)

falaApN tuwpN (with damm) [A desert, or waterless desert, in which one loses his way; or in which one is confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: or in which one perishes]: in the Ḳ, fulaAnN is erroneously put for falaApN; (TA;) [and in the CK, tuwapN for tuwohN; which last, in the CK, is made a pl.:] the pl. is OatowaAhN and OataAwiyhu: (Ḳ, TA:) the latter is a pl. of the former pl. (TA.)

huwa Oatowahu Aln-aAsi He is the most extraordinary of men [in deviating from, or losing, or missing, the right way; in losing his way: or] in confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see his right course: as also Oatayohu AlnAs: but the former is more common. (TA.)
[It may also mean He is the proudest, or vainest, of men.]

yaA mutaw-ahu [O misled! O misguided! or O thou who art made to deviate from, or lose, or miss, the right way!] is said in reviling: and one says also, maA baAlu caAka Almutaw-ahi yafoEalu kacaA [What is the case of that misled, or misguided, man, that he does thus?] (TA.)

1. tawiIa, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) in the dial. of Teiyi tawaI, (AAF, M,) aor. _a {yatowaIu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tawFI, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) It perished; came to an end; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) it passed away (T, M, Mgh) unhoped for: (T, M:) said of property. (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh.) Hence the saying, in a trad., laA tawaI EalaI maAli QmoriYK musolimK [There shall be no perishing of the property of a man that is a Muslim]: applied to the case of a man to whom is transferred the responsibility for a debt, and who dies insolvent; meaning that the responsibility shall return to him who transferred it. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: 4. AtwAhu He (God, M, Ḳ, or another, Ṣ) destroyed it, made an end of it, or caused it to perish or come to an end; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he made it away; (T, M;) namely, property, (Ṣ, M,) or his property. (T.)
See also art. tw.

entry.sense: tawK (Ṣ M, Mgh, Ḳ) and taAwK↓ (Mgh) Perishing; coming to an end; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) passing away (M, Mgh) unhoped for: (M:) applied to property. (Ṣ, M, Mgh.)
tawaMCN A perishing of property; its coming to an end; or becoming lost. (TA.)
tawiI-N Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding: (IAạr, M, Ḳ:) but vawiI-N, with v, is better known in this sense. (M.)
taAwK: see tawK.

AlX-uH-u matowaApN [Niggardliness, or avarice, is a cause of perishing to property]: a saying of the Arabs, meaning, if thou withhold property from its right disposal, God will make it to pass away in that which is not its right disposal. (M.)
2. tay-ayotu taMCK Hasanapa [and HasanFA I made, or wrote, a beautiful t]. (Lḥ, T.)
tayawiI-N; and qaSiydapN tayawiy-apN: see taAYiI-N, in art. twO.
tay-aA, and tay-aAka, and tay-aAlika: see art. tA.
tayotalN a dial. var., or a mispronunciation, of vayotalN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. taAHa, aor. yatiyHu, inf. n. tayoHN, It (a thing) was, or became, easy, and facilitated, or prepared. (Mṣb.) And taAHa lahu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n.; (TA;) and OutiyHa↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) It (a thing) was appointed, or ordained, to him, or for him: (Ṣ:) or was prepared for him; as also taAHa lahu, aor. yatuwHu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tawoHN: (TA:) and it (an event) was appointed, ordained, or decreed, to betide him. (L.) One says, waqaEa fiI maholakapK fataAHa lahu rajulN faOanoqacahu, [He fell into a place of destruction, and a man was appointed, or ordained, or prepared, for him, and he saved him]: (Lth, TA:) or faOutiyHa↓ lahu mano Oanoqacahu and taAHa lahu mano xal-aSahu [and there was appointed,, &c., for him he who saved him]. (A.)
taAHa fiI miXoyatihi He affected an inclining of his body from side to side in his gait, or manner of walking. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. AtAHhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UitaAHapN, (Mṣb,) He (God, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) made it (a thing) easy; facilitated it; (Mṣb;) or prepared it: (Ṣ, A;) whether good or evil; (TA;) lahu to him, or for him. (Ṣ, A.) One says, waqaEa fiI maholakapK faOataAHa Qll-ehu lahu mano Oanoqacahu [He fell into a place of destruction, and God appointed, or prepared, for him, him who saved him]. (Lth, TA.) And it is said in a trad., lOutiyHan-ahumo fitonapF [I will assuredly appoint, or ordain, or prepare, for them trial, or punishment, or conflict and faction, or the like]. (TA.) See also 1, in two places.

tay-iHaAnN, (T, Ṣ, A,) or tay-aHaAnN, (so in one copy of the Ṣ,) or both, (L, Ḳ,) like Xay-iMnN and Xay-aMnN applied to a horse, and hayib-aAnN and hayab-aAnN applied to a man, the only other instances of the kind, (L,) or the former is not allowable, (Ḥam p. 58,) so says Sb, as is stated in a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ, (TA,) applied to a horse, meaning That goes obliquely, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and bends over on each side; (Ṣ, A,) as also tay-aAHN↓ and mitoyaHN↓: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or that runs vehemently: and all signify, applied to a horse, fleet, swift, or excellent in running. (T, TA.) AHeyth explains the first and second as meaning Tall, or long. (TA.)

It is also applied to a man, meaning Who addresses himself to every generous action, and difficult affair: (T, TA:) or forward, officious, meddling, or a busybody, (A, and Ḥam pp. 58 and 505,) who says that which does not concern him: (Ḥam p. 505:) or who obtrudes himself, or interferes, in affairs: (Abu-l-ʼAlà El-Ma'arree in a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ, and Ḥam p. 58:) or, as also mitoyaHN↓, (Ṣ Ḳ,) and tay-aAHN↓, (Ḳ,) who obtrudes himself, or interferes, in that which does not concern him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or who falls into trials, or afflictions: (Ḳ:) or mitoyaHN↓, (TA,) which is also applied as an epithet to a heart, (Ṣ, A, TA,) signifies who obtrudes himself, or interferes, in everything, and falls into that which does not concern him; or who incessantly falls into trials, or afflictions; and its fem. is with p {tay-iHaAnapN}; (TA;) or who intrudes among a people whose affair, or business, is not his: (IAạr, T, TA:) and mitoyaAHN↓, (Ḳ,) applied to a man, (TA,) signifies much in motion; forward, officious, meddling, or a busybody. (Ḳ,* TA. [In the CK, AlEaryDu is erroneously put for AlEir-iyDu.])
tay-aAHN: see tay-iHaAnN, in two places.
mutaAHN A thing appointed, ordained, or decreed; as also mitoyaAHN↓. (Ḳ.)
mitoyaHN: see tay-iHaAnN, in three places.

hom.sense: mitoyaAHN: see tay-iHaAnN:
and mutaAHN.

entry.sense: taArN and taArapN (mentioned in this art. in the Ṣ): see the latter in art. twr.

hom.sense: tiyr A beam between two walls: (Ḳ:) [in which this word, with the art. Al is explained by AljaAYizu bayona AlHaAYiTiyna: in the M, AlHaAjizu byn AlHAYTyn, i. e. a partition between two gardens, or walled gardens of palm-trees: the former I regard as the right reading (though SM thinks the contrary); for it expresses a well-known meaning of tiyr in Persian; and it is said that tiyrN is] a Persian word, arabicized. (M.)
† Vanity, or a fond opinion of oneself, (Ḳ,) and pride. (TA.)

entry.sense: tay-aArN Waves: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb:) or waves of the sea, or of a great river, (M, IAth, Ḳ,) having a current; (Ḳ,* TA;) and its main body, or deep: (IAth, TA:) [in the present day, the current, or main current, of a sea or great river:] or vehemence of flow or current: (Mṣb:) accord. to some, of the measure faE-aAlN, from tyr; (Mṣb;) i. c., from tiyrN signifying “vanity” and “pride:” (TA:) accord. to others, of the measure fayoEaAlN, (Mṣb, TA,) from taAra, aor. yatuwru, though this verb is obsolete, (TA,) originally tayowaArN, the w being changed into I and then incorporated into the preceding I. (Mṣb.)
Applied to a man, ‡ Vain, or having a fond opinion of himself, (A, Ḳ,) and proud; (Ḳ;) who swells up like waves, in his vanity. (A.)
‡ A horse that rises like waves in his running.. (A.)
‡ A vein that runs, or flows, quickly, when cut. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
1. taAsa, [aor. yatiysu,] He (a kid) became a tayos. (M, TA.)

[Also, app., ‡ He became like a hegoat in stupidity: for what immediately follows appears to be the fem. of the imp. of this verb.] tiysiI↓ is a word used in declaring a thing to be vain, and false: (M, Ḳ:) or it is an execration; [for luEobapN, an evident mistake, which I find in copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA, I read laEonapN;] and a reproach: (Ḳ:) the vulgar say tiyziI, changing the s into z. (TA.) One says to a she-hyena, tiysiI jaEaAri, (A,* Ḳ,) meaning ‡ Be thou like the he-goat (tayos) in stupidity, O she-hyena: and these words are a proverb applied to a stupid man. (A, TA.) The same words were directed, by Aboo-Eiyoob, as is related in a trad., to be said to a guwl, (M, TA,) as though one said to her, Thou liest, or hast lied, O girl. (TA,) And one says to a man, tiysiI, and AiHomaqiI, [as though he were a she-hyena, or a woman,] when he speaks foolishly, or stupidly, or says what is not like anything. (AZ, TA.)

3. tAys qironahu, (A,) inf. n. mutaAyasapN and tiyaAsN, (A, Ḳ,) ‡ He strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, with his adversary; syn. maArasahu: (A:) [he strove with his adversary to repel him, like as a he-goat strives with another:] the inf. n. signifies the same as mumaArasapN, and mukaAbasapN, and mudaAfaEapN. (Ḳ.)
6. ttAys AlmaMCu ‡ The waves of the water conflicted, or dashed together. (A, TA.)

10. Aisotatoyasati AlEanozu ‡ The she-goat became like the tayos [or he-goat]: (M, [but in a copy of that work, for AlEanozu I find AlX-aApu,] A, Ḳ:) like Aisotanowaqa Aljamalu: (Ṣ:) a prov. applied to a vile man who becomes mighty, (A,) or who magnifies himself: (Ḳ:) one should not say AsttAst. (Th, M, TA.)

tayosN A he-goat; the male of the maEoz: (Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ:) and the male of the mountain-goat: (A, Ḳ) and of the gazelle: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) the female of the last [as well as of the first and second] is called EanozN: (Ṣ, M:) or that has completed a year: (A, Ḳ:) or a yearling he-goat: before the year it is called jadoIN: (AZ,* Mṣb, TA:)
pl. (of pauc., M) OatoyaAsN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OatoyusN, (M, TA,) and (of mult., M) tuyuwsN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tiyasapN and matoyuwsaMCu↓ [like maXoyuwxaMCu, q. v.]: (Ḳ:) the last [which is properly a quasi-pl. n.] signifies the same as tuyuwsN, (Ṣ,) or a herd of tuyuws. (M.) You say of the nak-aAH, [i. e. of him who marries often, or the like,] huwa mino mutoyuwsaMCi↓ baniI fulaAnK ‡ [lit. He is of the he-goats of the sons of such a one]. (A, TA.)
tayasN The quality, in a she-goat, of having horns like those of the mountain-goat, (Ḳ, TA,) in length. (TA.)
tiysiI: see 1.
EanozN tayosaMCN A she-goat having long horns, (M, A,) like the tayos: (A:) or having horns like those of the mountain-goat, (Ḳ, TA,) in length. (TA.)

fiyhi tayosiy-apN [In him is goatishness]: some say tayosuwsiy-apN↓, [in the TA tuyuwsiy-apN, but the former, which is found in the L as well as in the Ṣ and Ḳ, seems, from what here follows, to be the right,] (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and [in like manner, for kayofiy-apN they say] kayofuwfiy-apN, but [J says] I know not what is the truth thereof: (Ṣ:) the former word is preferable. (O, TA.)
tayosuwsiy-apN: see tayosiy-apN.
tay-aAsN A possessor of tuyuws [or he-goats]: (M:) or one who holds the tayos. (Ṣ, Ḳ: explained in the former by Al-aciI yumosiku Alt-ayosa: and in like manner in the latter, by mumosikuhu.)
matoyuwsaMCu: see tayosN, in two places.
tiyka: see art. tA.

hom.sense: 1. taAma, [aor. yatiymN, inf. n. tayomN,] He loved excessively: (T:) [or he became enslaved, or brought into subjection, by love; (see 2;) and so tty-m↓, as explained in Kull p. 165: (see Hub-u:) or his reason departed, and became disordered, in consequence of love and desire; for] tayomN signifies the departing of reason, and its becoming disordered, (T, TA,) in consequence of love and desire. (TA.)
He became alone, apart from others. (T, TA.)

taAmatohu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. tatiymuhu, (T,) inf. n. tayomN; (T, M, Ḳ;) and tay-amatohu↓, (T, M, Ḳ,) [which is the more common,] inf. n. tatoyiymN; (Ḳ;) She (a woman) enslaved him (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) by love of her, (M,) and brought him into subjection: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and she enslaved it, and brought it into subjection; namely, his heart: (Ṣ:) or she deprived him of his reason; disordered his reason. (T.) And taAmahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (M, Ḳ;) and ty-mhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) It (love, Ṣ, Ḳ, or love and desire, M, and excessive love, Ḳ) enslaved him, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and brought him into subjection. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
5: see 1.

8. Ait-aAma, (T, Ṣ,) inf. n. Ait-iyaAmN, (T, Ṣ, M,) He (a man) slaughtered his tiymap [q. v.]: (T, Ṣ, M:) and in like manner, Ait-aAmato, said of a woman: (T:) or At-yAm signifies the slaughtering camels, and sheep or goats, for no cause. (IAạr, T.)

tayomN i. q. EabodN [as meaning A slave, and a servant or worshipper or God or of a false god]: whence the names tayomu Qll-ehi [The servant of God] and tayomu All-aAti [The servant of El-Lát]: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) pl. tuyuwmN: it is originally an inf. n., from taAmuhu: or an epithet like its syn. EabodN: J says that it is from tay-amahu AlHub-u. (TA.)

hom.sense: niympN (as also tiYomapN, with hemz, Ḳ) A ewe, or she-goat, which her owner milks for himself, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in his abode, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of those which he has reared, (AʼObeyd, T,) not left to pasture where she pleases; (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) but sometimes slaughtered, when her owner is in want of flesh-meat: (AʼObeyd, T:) or one that is slaughtered in a time of famine: (AZ, T, M, Ḳ:) or one beyond forty, until the number attains to the next amount that requires one to be given for the poor rate: (M, Ḳ:) or one that is slaughtered gratuitously, not for a compensation, when persons desire flesh-meat. (AHeyth, T.)
Also A [kind of amulet, such as is called] tamiymap, that is hung upon a child: (Ḳ:) app. a contraction of tmymp. (TA.)

OaroDN tayomaMCu A [desert] land such as is termed qaforap, that causes one to lose his way and to perish: or a wide tract of land: (M, Ḳ:) or a land in which is no water: (T:) and tayomaMCu alone a [desert such as is termed] falaAp; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) because one loses his way therein: (T:) and a wide falaAp. (T.)
Alt-ayomaMCu The stars of AljawozaMC [app. meaning Gemini, also called Alt-awoCamaAni]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Oatoyamu [More, and most, enslaved by love]. Hence Oatoyamu mina Almuraq-iXi [More enslaved by love than El-Murakkish: a prov.: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 255]. (TA.)
matiymN: see what follows.

tiynN The tree of the balas [or common fig; ficus carica]: or the bls itself: (M:) [or both; i. e.] a certain well-known kind of tree; and the fruit thereof: (TA:) [or the latter only;] a certain thing that is eaten, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) well known: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) fresh and ripe, it is the most approved of fruits, and the most nutritious, and the least flatulent; drawing, dissolvent, having the property of opening obstructions of the liver and spleen, and laxative; and the eating much thereof engenders lice: (Ḳ: [the last word in this explanation in the Ḳ is muqomilN, which I render agreeably with the TḲ, having found no authoritative explanation of it: but in my own opinion, the meaning of this word is fattening, for qamila signifies “he became fat after being lean;” and my opinion is confirmed by what here follows:]) it is a pleasant fruit, having nothing redundant, and a nice food, quick of digestion, and a very useful medicine, for it has a laxative property, dissolves phlegm, purifies the kidneys, removes sand of the bladder, opens obstructions of the liver and spleen, and fattens the body: it is also said, in a trad., that it stops hemorrhoids, and is good for the gout: (Bḍ xcv. 1:) AḤn says, there are many kinds thereof; that of the desert, that of the cultivated land, that of the plains, and that of the mountains; and it is abundant in the land of the Arabs: and he adds, on the authority of an Arab of the desert, of the Saráh, that it is, in the Saráh, very abundant, and allowed to be commonly taken; and is eaten by the people there in its fresh state, and also dried and stored: (M:) the word is Arabic: (Mṣb:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {tiynapN}. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb.) This is what is meant in the Ḳur [xcv. 1], where it is said, waAlt-iyni waAlz-ayotuwni, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) accord. to I’Ab, (T, Ṣ, Bḍ, Jel,) and the generality of the interpreters: (Mṣb:) or these two words mean two mountains (Ṣ, M, Bḍ, Jel) of Syria, (Ṣ, Jel,) or of the Holy Land, (Bḍ,) that produce the two fruits thus named: (Jel:) or, accord. to a Syrian interpreter, certain mountains extending from Hulwán, to Hemdán, and the mountains of Syria: (Fr, T:) or Damascus and Jerusalem: (M, Bḍ:) or the mosque of Damascus and that of Jerusalem: (Bḍ:) or two mosques in Syria: accord. to AḤn, the former is the name of a mountain in the country of Ghatafán; but there is no mountain thus called in Syria. (M.)
Among the kinds of tiyn is that called tiynu Aljum-ayozi [The sycamore-fig; ficus sycomorus; also called the Egyptian fig]; describe voce jum-ayozN, q. v. (AḤn.)

[Alt-iynu AlUiforanojiI-u and Alt-iynu AlX-awokiI-u are appellations applied in the present day to The Indian fig, or prickly pear; cactus opuntia: Forskål (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. lxvii) applies the former name to the cochineal Indian fig; cactus cochinillifer.]
Alt-iynapu also signifies † The anus: (AḤn, M, Ḳ:) [opposed to Aljum-ayozapu as meaning “the pudendum muliebre.”.]
tiynaAnN: see art. tn.
tay-aAnN A seller of tiyn [or figs]. (TA.)
mataAnapN [originally matoyanapN] A fig-garden. (KL.) And OaroDN mataAnapN A land abounding with tiyn [or figs]. (TA.)

1. taAha, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yatiyhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. tiyhN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tayohN (Ḳ) and tayahaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) is syn. with taAha having for its aor. yatuwhu; (Mṣb, TA;) [and with TaAHa, aor. yaTiyHu and yaTuwHu;] signifying He deviated from, or lost, or missed, the right way; he lost his way; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) in the desert: (Mgh, Mṣb:) he was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (Mgh:) he went away in the land, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (Ṣ, TA:) [or his mind, or intellect, was, or became, disordered, confused, or unsound: (see taAha in art. twh:)] and he perished. (TA in art. twh.) You say also, taAhato bihi safiynatuhu His ship deviated from the right course with him. (TA.) And taAha Ean-iI baSaruka Thine eye, or thy sight, passed me over; syn. taxaT-aI. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) taAha baSarahu [in the CK, erroneously, qaSoruhu] signifies also taAfa, (Ḳ, TA,) [in the CK nAfa,] i. e., accord. to 'Arrám, He looked at a thing continually, or continuously (fiI dawaAmK [app. as one confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see aright]). (Aboo-Turáb, TA.)

Also, taAha, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yatiyhu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tiyhN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and tiyahN is said to be a dial. var. of this, but is doubtful; (MF;) [like taAha having for its aor. yatuwhu;] He magnified himself; or behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and he affected to be commended for, or praised for, or he gloried in, that which he did not possess; [i. e. he was, or became, conceited, or vain-glorious; or he behaved conceitedly, or vain-gloriously;] or he overpassed the due bounds in elegance of mind or manners or address or speech or person or attire and the like, and arrogated to himself superiority therein, through pride: (Ḳ:)he overpassed the due bounds in elegance of mind or manners or address or speech or person or attire and the like, and arrogated to himself superiority therein, through pride: (Ḳ:) [or rather, he was, or became, vain; or he behaved vainly: for] Er-Rághib makes a distinction between muEojabN and taAYihN; saying that the mEjb believes himself with respect to the opinion or judgment that he forms of himself indecisively, from evidence outweighed in probability; whereas the tAYh believes himself decisively. (MF and TA in art. Ejb.) One says, huwa yatiyhu EalaI qawomihi [He behaves proudly, or conceitedly, or vainly, towards his people]. (TA.)

2. ty-hhu i. q. taw-ahahi [and Tay-aHahu and Taw-aHahu], i. e., He made him to deviate from, or lose, or miss, the right way; made him to lose his way: (Mṣb:) [or he made him to be, or become, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his tight course:, &c.: see 1:] he destroyed, or lost, or left or neglected, him or it. (Ḳ.) And ty-h nafosahu He made himself to be, or become, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (Ṣ, TA;) as also taw-ahahaA and Taw-aHahaA: (Ṣ:) or he destroyed himself. (TA.)
4. maA Oatoyahahu: see maA Oatowahahu, in art. twh.
10. AsttAhhu: see art. twh.
tayohN: see tiyhN.

tiyhN [originally an inf. n.: see 1, throughout:] A mafaAzap [i. e. desert, or waterless desert,, &c.,] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) in which one loses his way, (Ṣ,) wherein is no sign, or mark, whereby one may be guided therein; as also tayohaMCu↓: (Mṣb:) pl. OatoyaAhN and OataAwiyhN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter of which is a pl. of the former pl., (TA,) and OataAwihapN. (Meyd, in Freytag's Lex.) [Hence,] Alt-iyhu, [also called tiyhu baniI UisoraAYiyla,] The place [or desert] in which the Children of Israel lost their way, between Egypt and the 'Akabeh [at the head of the eastern gulf of the Red Sea], unable to find the way of egress from it. (TA.)

OaroDN tiyhN and tayohN↓ and tayohaMCu↓ (Ḳ) and matiyhapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) originally [matoyihapN,] of the measure mafoEilapN, (Ṣ,) and mutiyhapN↓ and matoyahapN↓ and matoyapN↓ (Ḳ) and mutoyihapN↓ (TA) A land wherein one loses his way, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) wide, and having in it no signs, or marks, of the way, nor mountains nor hills. (TA.) And baladN Oatoyahu↓ A country to which, and in which, one cannot find his way. (TA.)
tayohaMCu: see tiyhN, in two places.
tayohaAnN: see taAYihN, in two places.

Also, and tay-ahaAnN↓ and tay-ihaAnN↓, Daring, or bold; who pursues a random, or heedless, course, without any certain aim or object, in affairs: applied to a man: and in like manner to a camel: and, with p {tayohaAnapN}, to a she-camel. (TA.)
tay-ahaAnN and tay-ihaAnN: see tayohaAnN: and see also taAYihN.
tay-aAhN: see taAYihN, in two places.

taAYihN Deviating from, or losing, or missing, the right way; losing his way; (Mgh; see also art. twh;) and so tayohaAnN↓ and [in an intensive sense, like mitoyahN,] tay-aAhN↓: (Ḳ:) deviating from the right way and magnifying himself or behaving proudly or haughtily or insolently: or deviating from the right way and being confounded or perplexed, unable to see his right course. (TA.)
‡ Deviating from the right way in opinion: (Mgh:) desiring a thing and unable to find the right way. (Mṣb.)

Magnifying himself; or behaving proudly, haughtily, or insolently: affecting to be commended for or praised for, or glorying in, that which he does not possess; or overpassing the due bounds in elegance of mind or manners, &c.: [see 1, last sentence but one: it is best rendered behaving proudly, or conceitedly, or vainly:] and in like manner tay-aAhN↓; (Ḳ;) but this has an intensive signification; [meaning, like mitoyahN, very proud or conceited or vain;] (TA;) and tayohaAnN↓ and tay-ahaAnN↓ and tay-ihaAnN↓: (Ḳ:) or only taAYihN and tay-aAhN, accord. to IDrd. (TA.)
huwa Oatoyahu Aln-aAsi: see Oatowahu in art. twh, where it is explained on the authority of the TA. [In the Ṣ it seems to be indicated by the context that the meaning is He is the proudest of men.]
See also tiyhN last sentence.
matoyahN: see tiyhN.
mitoyahN A man having much tiyh [meaning pride, or conceit, or vanity]: or who deviates from, or loses, or misses, the right way, or who loses his way, much, or often. (TA.)
matiyhapN and matoyahapN and mutiyhapN and mutoyihapN: see tiyhN
